Description: THE PLAN OF WORK REFLECTS A JOINT EFFORT OF RESEARCH AND EXTENSION ACTIVITIES PLANNED BY CLEMSON AND SOUTH CAROLINA STATE (SC STATE) UNIVERSITIES TO BENEFIT AGRIBUSINESS, COMMUNITIES, AND CITIZENS OF SOUTH CAROLINA FROM 2022 THROUGH 2026. SC STATE RESEARCH IS BASED ON THE DISCOVERY AND DELIVERY OF NEW KNOWLEDGE THROUGH SCIENCE-BASED, RELEVANT RESEARCH LEADING TO DISCOVERIES SPECIFIC TO SOUTH CAROLINA'S NEEDS. FOCUS AREAS INCLUDE ADVANCING THE COMPETITIVENESS OF THE AGRICULTURE AND FORESTRY INDUSTRY, ENHANCING THE ECONOMIC POTENTIAL OF RURAL COMMUNITIES, SAFEGUARDING THE FOOD SUPPLY, PRESERVING NATURAL RESOURCES, AND PREPARING THE YOUNGER GENERATIONS TO BECOME PRODUCTIVE CITIZENS. THERE IS CONTINUED EMPHASIS ON EVALUATING ALL RESEARCH AND EXTENSION ACTIVITIES AND PROVIDING QUALITY PERFORMANCE INFORMATION TO STAKEHOLDERS THROUGH EXTENSION AND OUTREACH ACTIVITIES. AS PART OF THE LAND-GRANT MISSION, THE OBJECTIVE OF THE SC STATE PROGRAM IS TO RAISE THE EDUCATIONAL CONSCIOUSNESS AND AWARENESS OF NATIONAL ISSUES THAT IMPACT SOUTH CAROLINIANS, WITH SPECIAL EMPHASIS ON LIMITED RESOURCE CLIENTELE, IN ORDER TO IMPROVE THEIR QUALITY OF LIFE. IT IS AN ORGANIZED RESEARCH AND EXTENSION SYSTEM THAT ADDRESSES QUALITY OF LIFE OPPORTUNITIES FOR RESIDENTS. THE PROGRAM PROVIDES EFFECTIVE STAKEHOLDER OUTREACH PROGRAMS AND SERVICES IN THE AREA OF AGRICULTURE/NATURAL RESOURCES, FAMILY LIFE, HEALTH AND NUTRITION, YOUTH DEVELOPMENT, AGRIBUSINESS, COMMUNITY ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT, EDUCATION AND TECHNOLOGY. SC STATE VALUES THE INTEGRATION OF RESEARCH, TEACHING, AND OUTREACH. THE RESEARCH PROVIDES ADEQUATE FUNDING TO FACULTY, STAFF, AND STUDENTS TO BECOME ENGAGED IN ORGANIZED RESEARCH EFFORTS/OPPORTUNITIES TO ADDRESS PROBLEMS AND ISSUES OF CONCERN. IN CONJUNCTION WITH THE SC STATE RESEARCH, THE EXTENSION UNIT DELIVERS RESEARCH-BASED PROGRAMS/ACTIVITIES DESIGNED TO HELP STAKEHOLDERS/CLIENTELE ENHANCE THEIR QUALITY OF LIFE, IN ORDER TO RESPOND TO ENVIRONMENTAL CHANGES. BOTH UNITS WORK COHESIVELYFOR THE BETTERMENT OF THE CITIZENS OF SOUTH CAROLINA. THE SC STATE RESEARCH PROGRAM IS THE CATALYST THAT HAS KEPT THE UNIVERSITY AT THE FOREFRONT OF AGRICULTURAL AND RURAL RESEARCH PROBLEMS AND ISSUES CONFRONTING SOUTH CAROLINA. THE RESEARCHERS ARE EMERGING LEADERS IN THEIR FIELDS, AND THEY ARE WORKING TO COMBAT OBESITY AMONG YOUTH, ENHANCING BIOREMEDIATION TECHNOLOGY, IMPROVING FOOD SAFETY AND SECURITY, DEVELOPING OPTIMIZATION MODELS THAT WILL AID IN DECREASING LOGISTICS COSTS FOR BIOFUEL AND IDENTIFYING TECHNIQUES TO INCREASE ACADEMIC PERFORMANCE OF STUDENTS IN PUBLIC SCHOOLS. SC STATE RESEARCHERS AND EXTENSION PROFESSIONALS ARE TRAINING UNDERGRADUATE AND GRADUATE STUDENTS TO BECOME THE NATION'S NEXT GENERATION OF BIOLOGISTS, ENGINEERS, ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENTISTS, AND EDUCATORS.

THROUGH A CONSULTATION PROCESS, DELAWARE ESTABLISHED THE CRITICAL ISSUES THAT HARMONIZE WITH THE NATIONAL USDA FOOD, AGRICULTURE, NATURAL RECOURSES, AND HUMAN SCIENCES STRATEGIC GOALS. THESE ISSUES INCLUDE BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO: (1) A SAFE <(>&<)> SECURE FOOD SUPPLY FOR HUMAN NUTRITION AND HEALTH (NUTRITION AND WELLNESS) TO GET MORE MINORITY STUDENTS' INVOLVEMENT IN FOOD SAFETY EDUCATION TO HELP ADDRESS THE FOOD SAFETY ISSUES FOR BOTH PRODUCERS AND CONSUMERS. ADDRESSING THESE CONCERNS WILL HELP TO GENERATE HIGHLY SKILLED PROFESSIONALS REQUIRED TO REVOLUTIONIZE AND MEET REGULATORY DIRECTIVES AND CONSUMER NEEDS, AND TO INCORPORATE SCIENCE INTO GLOBAL STANDARDS; 2) ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDSHIP IN A CHANGING CLIMATE IS ANOTHER AREA DSU IS PLAYING A ROLE TO CONTRIBUTE TO THE UNDERSTANDING OF HOW TO CONSERVE, PROTECT, AND CREATE A MORE SUSTAINABLE ENVIRONMENT AS WELL AS THE VALUE OF BIODIVERSITY AND THE ECOSYSTEM SERVICES PROVIDED BY DIFFERENT WILDLIFE TO ENSURE SUSTAINABLE AND ABUNDANT FOODSUPPLY FOR THE U.S. AND THE WORLD; AND 3) SUSTAINABLE PRODUCTION SYSTEMS FOR AGRICULTURAL AND URBAN LANDSCAPES. UNDERSTANDING WHERE IN THE LANDSCAPE THAT BOTH ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS (SUCH AS FROM AGRICULTURE, DEVELOPMENT, AND CLIMATE CHANGE) AND ECOSYSTEM SERVICES (BENEFITS TO HUMANS) OCCUR CAN HELP US PLAN FOR MORE SUSTAINABLE FUTURES. THE CURRENT BIOMASS PRE-TREATMENT TECHNOLOGIES SUCH AS DILUTED ACID AND HOT WATER EMPLOYED TO REMOVE LIGNIN FROM L IGNOCELLULOSIC BIOMASSES (LIGNIN RECALCITRANCE) ARE EXPENSIVE AND NOT COST EFFECTIVE TO BE DEPLOYED IN COMMERCIAL SCALE. OUR PROGRAM IS LEVERAGING MOLECULAR BIOTECHNOLOGY APPROACHES TO ADDRESS BOTH LIGNIN RECALCITRANCE AND NUTRIENT DEFICIENCIES. THIS INITIATIVE HELPS TO SUPPORT ENERGY SECURITY AND THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE BIOECONOMY FROM RENEWABLE NATURAL RESOURCES IN THE U.S. THESE RESEARCH PROJECTS ARE FOCUSED ON DEVELOPING INTERVENTIONS AND STRATEGIES FOR ADAPTATION TO GLOBAL CLIMATE CHANGE AND ACCELERATE THEIR DELIVERY OF BEST PRACTICES TO LIMITED RESOURCE FARMERS AND LANDOWNERS IN THE STATE OF DELAWARE AND THE NATION.

THROUGH THE INSTITUTE OF AGRICULTURAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL RESEARCH, THE GOAL OF AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH AT TENNESSEE STATE UNIVERSITY IS TO CREATE AND COMMUNICATE NEW KNOWLEDGE IN THE AGRICULTURAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES. THROUGH OUR INNOVATIVE RESEARCH, WE ADDRESS THE NEEDS OF HUMANKIND, FOCUSING ON FINDING SOLUTIONS TO CHALLENGES FACED BY SOCIALLY AND ECONOMICALLY DISADVANTAGED GROUPS, AND CONTRIBUTING TO THE PROSPERITY OF THE CITIZENS OF TENNESSEE, THE NATION, AND THE WORLD. RESEARCH IN TENNESSEE STATE UNIVERSITY AGRICULTURE IS ORGANIZED TO ADDRESS THE CRITICAL ISSUES DESCRIBED BELOW. ENHANCING BIODIVERSITY AND ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY SAFEGUARDING AND ENHANCING THE NATURAL RESOURCE ENVIRONMENT HAS BECOME INCREASINGLY COMPLEX WITHIN ENVIRONMENTAL, SOCIAL, RESOURCE AND PERSONAL CONTEXTS. THROUGH COLLABORATION AMONG RESEARCHERS, INDUSTRY, PRODUCERS, ENVIRONMENTAL GROUPS, AND GOVERNMENT, WE ARE HELPING PRESERVE A DIVERSE AND RESILIENT ENVIRONMENT FOR FUTURE GENERATIONS. ENRICHING OUR ECONOMY HELPING FARMS AND AGRICULTURE BUSINESSES BECOME MORE PROFITABLE AND INDIVIDUALS BECOME FINANCIALLY SECURE BOOSTS THE LOCAL, STATE, AND NATIONAL ECONOMIES. OUR PROGRAMS STRIVE TO STRENGTHEN THE ECONOMIC VIABILITY OF ALL FACETS OF AGRIBUSINESS, AND IMPROVE THE FINANCIAL LITERACY OF TENNESSEANS AND BEYOND SO THEY MAY BUILD AND PROTECT WEALTH FOR THEMSELVES AND FUTURE GENERATIONS. STRENGTHENING OUR HEALTH MAKING HEALTHY CHOICES IS IMPORTANT FOR HUMANS, ANIMALS, AND EVEN OUR PLANET. AS A LEADER IN NUTRITION, ANIMAL WELFARE, AND ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION, WE ARE WORKING TO UNDERSTAND HOW FOOD, PHYSICAL ACTIVITY, AND SOCIAL CONNECTIONS AFFECT OVERALL HEALTH. FROM FOOD SAFETY TO DISEASE PREVENTION AND MAINTENANCE TO THE STATE OF OUR ENVIRONMENT, THESE EFFORTS WILL HELP AMERICANS AND THE REST OF THE WORLD LEAD HEALTHIER LIVES FOR GENERATIONS TO COME. SUPPORTING FOOD, FIBER, AND ENERGY SYSTEMS SAFE, SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURAL SYSTEMS THAT ARE SOCIALLY, ECONOMICALLY, AND ENVIRONMENTALLY RESPONSIBLE ARE KEY TO ENHANCING THE LIVES OF TENNESSEANS AND SUPPORTING A GROWING GLOBAL POPULATION. WE ARE EXPLORING WAYS TO DELIVER DISCOVERIES USING A SYSTEMS APPROACH TO AGRICULTURE PRODUCTIVITY THAT WILL PROVIDE CUSTOMIZABLE SOLUTIONS FOR PRODUCERS. UTILIZING FACULTY IN THE IN THE DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES AND THE DEPARTMENT OF HUMAN SCIENCES, OUR RESE ARCH ADDRESSES THESE CRITICAL ISSUES THROUGH FACULTY GROUPS IN THE PLANT, ANIMAL, FOOD, AND HUMAN SCIENCES. THESE FACULTY-LED GROUPS FACILITATE THE IDENTIFICATION OF RESEARCH PRIORITIES WITHIN OUR CRITICAL ISSUES THAT ARE OF IMPORTANCE TO STAKEHOLDER GROUPS. WE CONDUCT RESEARCH IN AGRICULTURAL LEADERSHIP, EDUCATION AND COMMUNICATION THAT BRIDGES THE GAP BETWEEN THE GENERAL PUBLIC AND SCIE NTISTS WORKING TO SOLVE CURRENT AND EMERGING CHALLENGES RELATED TO SUSTAINABLY FEEDING AN EVER-GROWING POPULATION UNDER VARIOUS ENVIRONMENTAL AND SOCIETAL COMPLICATIONS. THIS RESEARCH ALSO BUILDS HUMAN AND INSTITUTIONAL CAPACITYNEEDED BY A VARIETY OF PUBLIC, PRIVATE, AND NONPROFIT EMPLOYERS IN THE AGRICULTURE SECTOR. ALSO STUDIED ARE WAYS TO DEVELOP HUMAN CAPACITY AND PROVIDE LEADERSHIP WITHIN COMMUNITIES. MUCH RESEARCH IN THIS AREA ALSO IDENTIFIES THE IMPACT OF TECHNOLOGY IN AGRICULTURAL EDUCATION, TECHNOLOGIES SUCH AS LECTURE-CAPTURE, DRONES, ROBOTS, EXTENDED REALITY, AND 360-DEGREE VIDEO. IN THE AREA OF AGRIBUSINESS, WE HAVE STRONG APPLIED-RESEARCH COMPONENT. WE PREPARE STUDENTS, FARMERS, AND STAKEHOLDERS IN THE USE OF ECONOMIC ANALYSIS AND MANAGEMENT COMPETENCIES TO TAKE ON THE CHALLENGES AND OPPORTUNITIES OF A DYNAMIC AGRI-FOOD SYSTEM. THE RESEARCH AREA EMPHASIZES PROMOTING, DEVELOPING, AND IMPROVING THE UTILIZATION OF RESEARCH, OUTREACH CAPABILITIES AND OPPORTUNITIES INVOLVING AGRIBUSINESSES, NATURAL RESOURCES AND COMMUNITIES. MAIN ACTIVITIES INCLUDE INVESTIGATIONS ON THE SOLE OR COMBINATION OF STRATEGIES FOR PROFITABILITY, AND THE SUSTAINABILITY, SURVIVAL, EFFICIENCY AND EFFECTIVENESS OF AGRICULTURALOPERATIONS, PARTICULARLY SMALL FARM OPERATIONS. ANTICIPATED RESULTS INCLUDE FARMERS' ADOPTION OF NEW CROPS; INVESTMENT FOR ALTERNATE INCOME DIVERSIFICATION STRATEGIES SUCH AS AGRITOURISM; ENHANCED KNOWLEDGE ON BENEFITS AND COSTS OF SUSTAINABLE PRACTICES; IMPROVED FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT AND MARKETING STRATEGIES AND DEVELOPMENT OF ENTREPRENEURSHIP SKILLS. RESEARCH IN ANIMAL SCIENCE IS DIRECTED AT IMPROVING LIVESTOCK PRODUCTION SYSTEMS BY GENERATING NOVEL FINDINGS THAT IMPACT ANIMAL WELL-BEING AND PERFORMANCE. SUB-DISCIPLINES SUCH AS GENETICS, HEALTH, NUTRITION, AND REPRODUCTIVE PHYSIOLOGY ARE INTEGRATED IN THE POULTRY AND RUMINANT LIVESTOCK RESEARCH ENDEAVORS. RESEARCH SPANS FROM BASIC, MOLECULAR MODELS TO APPLIED, WHOLE-ANIMAL SYSTEMS. PRIMARY END-USERS OF THE RESEARCH FINDINGS ARE LIVESTOCK PRODUCERS THAT ARE OFTEN SOCIALLY-DISADVANTAGED, RESOURCE-LIMITED OWNER-OPERATORS OF SMALL-SCALE ENTERPRISES. WE HAVE RESEARCH EFFORTS DIRECTED AT ELUCIDATING, MOLECULARLY AND FUNCTIONALLY, ANIMAL IMMUNE AND METABOLIC GENES. IN PARTICULAR, THOSE GENES THAT HAVE ANTIMICROBIAL ACTIVITIES AND THERAPEUTIC POTENTIAL. WE ARE USING COMBINED APPROACHES OF BIOINFORMATICS, GENETICS AND MOLECULAR BIOLOGY TO ELUCIDATE GENES OR GENE FAMILIES THAT ARE POTENTIALLY IMPORTANT IN ANIMAL HEALTH. SOME OF OUR ANIMAL PRODUCTION RESEARCH EMPHASIZES GOAT PRODUCTION. PROJECTS HAVE FOCUSED ON EVALUATING BREEDS TO GENERATE RECOMMENDATIONS ON HOW TO BEST USE THE DIFFERENT BREEDS FOR ENHANCED COMMERCIAL MEAT GOAT PRODUCTION. PRODUCERS HAVE MODIFIED THEIR GENETIC MANAGEMENT DECISION-MAKING LEADING TO IMPROVED HERD HEALTH, PERFORMANCE, AND ECONOMIC RETURN. IN POULTRY RESEARCH, THE CURRENT DEMAND FOR POULTRY AND POULTRY PRODUCTS REQUIRES A GAIN IN GENETIC POTENTIAL COMPLEMENTED WITH NUTRITIONAL REGIMENS THAT MAXIMIZE GROWTH AND IMPROVE EFFICIENCY OF FEED UTILIZATION. EXAMINATION OF OPTIMAL FEED COMPOSITION AND ALLOCATION IS OPTIMIZING SPECIFIC AMINO ACID CONCENTRATIONS. FEEDING THESE NEW LEVELS OF AMINO ACIDS WILLREDUCE FEEDING COST IN GUINEA FOWL PRODUCTION. OBESITY AND CHRONIC DISEASE PREVENTION IS ADDRESSED IN A PROGRAM THAT FOCUSES ON DEVELOPING A SMARTPHONE APPLICATION FOR WIC FAMILIES THAT WILL PROVIDE TOOLS TO MAKE USING THEIR BENEFITS EASIER WHILE PROVIDING HEALTHY RECIPES, NUTRITION EDUCATION, AND A GOAL TRACKING TOOL. HEALTHY EATING EXTENDS BEYOND LIMITING INTAKE OF FATS AND CALORIES. OUR NUTRITION RESEARCH IS AIMED AT UNDERSTANDING THE EFFECTS AND MECHANISMS OF FOOD-DERIVED BIOACTIVE COMPOUNDS AND THEIR ROLE IN COMBATING HUMAN CHRONIC DISEASES SUCH CANCER, OBESITY, AND DIABETES. RESEARCH WILL PROVIDE DIRECT EVIDENCE THAT HUMAN CHRONIC DISEASE CAN BE PREVENTED OR TREATED BY SELECTING FOODS HAVING HIGH LEVELS OF BIOACTIVE COMPOUNDS. FOOD IS A CORNERSTONE OF HUMAN EXISTENCE. ONGOING FOOD SCIENCE RESEARCH FOCUSES ON IMPROVING THE SAFETY, QUALITY, SHELF-LIFE, NUTRIENT PROFILE AND SENSORY ATTRIBUTES OF NOVEL FOOD INGREDIENTS, DEVELOPING AND VALIDATING ADVANCED AND INNOVATIVE TECHNOLOGIES FOR FOOD PROCESSING, MANUFACTURING, PACKAGING, AND SANITATION TO EFFECTIVELY REDUCE THE PRESENCE OF FOODBORNE PATHOGENS. ALSO, WE ARE DEVELOPING AND VALIDATING NOVEL STRATEGIES FOR THE EFFECTIVE CONTROL OF PERSISTENT RESERVOIRS OF FOODBORNE PATHOGENS AND MITIGATING ANTIMICROBIAL RESISTANCE ACROSS THE FOOD CHAIN. FOR EXAMPLE, WE ARE LOOKING AT NEW WAYS TO REMOVE PATHOGENS FROM FOODS BY PRECISELY DEFINING THE LIMITS OF USING UV LIGHT AS A SUBSTITUTE FOR PASTEURIZATION TO ACHIEVE A SPECIFIED LETHALITY FOR DEADLY AGENTS IN FOODS. THIS PROCESS IS USING ADVANCED MATHEMATICAL AND COMPUTATIONAL MODELS. TECHNIQUES DEVELOPED IN THIS PROGRAM ARE ALSO BEING INVESTIGATED FOR POSSIBLE APPLICATION TO CONTROL THE SPREAD OF SARS-COV-2 AND OTHER VIRUSES. OTHER FOOD SCIENCE RESEARCH IS ADDRESSING THE PROBLEM OF CAMPYLOBACTER. THIS ORGANISM IS ONE OF THE MOST COMMON CAUSES OF DIARRHEAL ILLNESS IN THE UNITED STATES. DUE TO THE PREVALENCE OF CAMPYLOBACTER IN RAW CHICKEN PRODUCTS, ROUTINE AND RELIABLE MONITORING IS NECESSARY TO REDUCE ITS IMPACT UPON HUMAN HEALTH. THE METHOD BEING DEVELOPED IS INTENDED TO BE USED BY FOOD INDUSTRY AND REGULATORY TESTING LABORATORIES TO FACILITATE IMPROVED IDENTIFICATION OF CAMPYLOBACTER IN PROCESSING FACILITIES AND FINAL PRODUCTS. TO MITIGATE THE SPREAD OF ANTIMICROBIAL RESISTANT CONTAMINANTS IN FOODS, WE HAVE RESEARCH THAT HAS GENERATED A SERIES OF HOTSPOT MAPS THAT WILL BE USED IN WORKSHOPS/WEBINARS TO ILLUSTRATE ANTIMICROBIAL RESISTANT BACTERIAL COMMUNITIES ON PRODUCER'S FARMS. BY USING PERSONALIZED HOTSPOT MAPS THAT DISPLAY THE FREQUENCY OF ANTIBIOTIC RESISTANT BACTERIA IN FARMS, PRODUCERS WILL MAKE INFORMED DECISIONS ON THE USAGE OF ANTIBIOTICS IN THEIR LIVESTOCK, THUS REDUCING THE THREAT OF CONTAMINATION OF FOOD CROPS FERTILIZED WITH THE ANTIMICROBIAL-RESISTANT MANURE. RESEARCH IN NATURAL RESOURCES USES MULTIDISCIPLINE APPROACHES TO UNDERSTAND AND ATTENUATE PROBLEMS CAUSED BY CLIMATE CHANGE, LAND DE GRADATION, LOSS OF BIODIVERSITY, EMERGING CONTAMINANTS, AND ANTHROPOGENIC STRESSORS. TRADITIONAL AND CUTTING-EDGE CHEMISTRY METHODS ARE USED TO STUDY FATE OF CHEMICALS IN THE ENVIRONMENT, THE INTERACTION OF HAZARDOUS SUBSTANCES WITH SOILS AND WATER AND BIOGEOCHEMICAL CYCLES. BIOTECHNOLOGY IS USED TO STUDY AND RECTIFY HARMFUL ALGAL BLOOMS, WILDLIFE DISEASES AND PARASITES, MONITOR RARE AND ENDANGERED SPECIES, AND SOIL HEALTH. GEOGRAPHIC INFORMATION SYSTEMS, REMOTE SENSING AND ADVANCED STATISTICS ARE USED TO MODEL CLIMATE CHANGE ON A LARGE SCALE, WILDLIFE ECOSYSTEMS, DETERMINE THE VALUE OF ECOSYSTEM SERVICES AND DOCUMENT WATER RESOURCES. OUR RESEARCH TAKES PLACE IN CHEMISTRY LABS, COMPUTER LABS, RURAL AND URBAN SETTINGS AS WE SEEK TO SUSTAIN AND IMPROVE THE NATION'S NATURAL RESOURCES. IN ADDITION TO RESEARCH, WE BUILD INSTITUTIONAL CAPACITY AND STRENGTHEN OUR ENVIRONMENTAL PROGRAM THROUGH BRIDGE PROGRAMS, STUDENT RECRUITMENT AND MENTORING, STRATEGIC PARTNERSHIPS, AGGRESSIVE PROPOSAL WRITING AND CURRICULUM DEVELOPMENT. THE GOAL IS TO DEVELOP A STRONG DIVERSE WORKFORCE IN THE NATURAL RESOURCES THAT REFLECTS OUR NATION'S DEMOGRAPHICS. PLANT SCIENCE RESEARCH INCLUDES DIVERSE FIELDS IN AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION SYSTEMS WITH A FOCUS ON DEVELOPING AND APPLYING SCIENTIFIC AND BIOTECHNOLOGICAL PRINCIPLES TO IMPROVE CROP PRODUCTIVITY, REDUCE LOSSES FROM DISEASE, INSECT PESTS, AND TOXIC METAL STRESS; IN ADDITION TO IMPROVING THE UNDERSTANDING OF PLANT STRESS TOLERANCE MECHANISMS FOR HANDLING HEAT, DROUGHT AND OTHER STRESS FACTORS. RESEARCH INCLUDES THE DEVELOPMENT OF NEW TECHNOLOGIES FOR IMPROVING THE PRODUCTION OF RENEWABLE ENERGY SOURCES AND DEVELOPMENT OF ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS FOR REDUCING PESTICIDE INPUTS IN CROP PRODUCTION SYSTEMS SUCH AS MICROBIAL-BASED PRODUCTS, PHEROMONES, AND PLANT OILS, PLANT GENETIC RESISTANCE AND BY BROADENING SOYBEAN GENETIC DIVERSITY FOR FUTURE GAINS IN CROP PRODUCTIVITY AND PREPAREDNESS FOR EMERGING NEW DISEASES AND INSECT PESTS. CROPS ADDRESSED ARE DIVERSE, INCLUDING VEGETABLES, CORN, SOYBEANS, ORNAMENTAL NURSERY CROPS, BIOENERGY CROPS, HYDROPONICS, AND URBAN AGRICULTURE. TECHNOLOGICAL CONTRIBUTIONS FROM THIS RESEARCH INCLUDE INCREASING CROP DIVERSITY BY INTRODUCING NEW EXOTIC VEGETABLES AND AMARANTH, DEVELOPING NEW CROP ALTERNATIVES LIKE HEMP, AND BIOFUEL ALTERNATIVES SUCH AS PERENNIAL SWITCHGRASS AND WINTER CANOLA THAT HAVE IMPROVED DIGESTIBILITY AND PROCESSING, AND DEVELOPING NEW PLANTS TOLERANT TO HEAT STRESS. OTHER RESEARCH ACTIVITIES ON BEST CROP MANAGEMENT PRACTICES, NITROGEN APPLICATION RATES TO ENHANCE YIELD AND FEEDSTOCK CHARACTERISTICS, THE BEST WINTER CANOLA VARIETIES AND NITROGEN RATES FOR TENNESSEE DELIVER SERVICES OF VALUE TO SOCIETY. AN OVERALL LACK OF CROP DIVERSITY IN THE AGRICULTURAL SYSTEMS OF THE SOUTHEASTERN UNITED STATES INCREASES THE THREATS OF DISEASE EPIDEMICS, INSECT PEST OUTBREAKS OR RISKS OF CROP FAILURE DUE TO ABIOTIC STRESSES. IT IS IMPORTANT TO DEVELOP ALTERNATIVE CROPS FOR PRODUCTIVE SYSTEMS. RESEARCH TO ADDRESS THIS ISSUE HAS PRODUCED THE RELEASE OF TWO GRAIN AMARANTH VARIETIES AND THE RELEASE OF TWO GRAIN LEGUME VARIETIES. THESE ALTERNATIVE CROPS GIVE PRODUCERS OPTIONS IN SELECTING PRODUCTION MARKETS. ANOTHER PROGRAM LEADING TO CROP DIVERSITY IS EXAMINING THE ROLE OF SWEET SORGHUM AS A POTENTIAL DEDICATED US BIOFUEL CROP. THIS PROGRAM IS ESTABLISHING INNOVATIVE PROTOCOLS FOR SWEET SORGHUM GENETIC ENHANCEMENT. AS MORE KNOWLEDGE IS GAINED ABOUT THE INTERCONNECTEDNESS OF HUMAN IMPACTS ON THE EARTH, THE ROLE OF ANTIBIOTIC CONTAMINATION ON SOIL HEALTH IS BEING EXAMINED. MICRONUTRIENT DEFICIENCY IS A MAJOR CONCERN IN THE PRODUCTION OF SOME CROPS, SOME OF OUR RESEARCH WILL SIGNIFICANTLY IMPROVE THE UNDERSTANDING THE BIOGEOCHEMICAL CYCLING OF MICRONUTRIENTS IN THE PRESENCE OF ANTIBIOTICS. THREATS FROM DISEASE AND INSECT PESTS ARE BEING ADDRESSED IN A NUMBER OF RESEARCH PROGRAMS. PLANT DISEASE IS A MAJOR THREAT TO GLOBAL FOOD PRODUCTION COSTING THE US ECONOMY AN ESTIMATED $33 BILLION ANNUALLY IN YIELD LOSS. WE HAVE RESEARCH THAT IS FOCUSED ON UNEARTHING THE MOLECULAR SECRETS OF PLANT-BACTERIAL INTERACTIONS THAT RESULT IN TWO IMPORTANT DISEASES OF VEGETABLES - BACTERIAL SOFT ROT OF ALL VEGETABLES AND BACTERIAL WILT OF CUCURBITS CROPS. RESEARCH HAS IDENTIFIED ACCESSIONS RESISTANT TO WILT DISEASE AND WHICH CAN BE EMPLOYED IN A BREEDING PROGRAM FOR RESISTANCE CULTIVARS. OTHER DISEASE RESEARCH IS EXAMINING THE USE OF BIOCONTROL AGENTS FOR DISEASE MANAGEMENT. THESE ALTERNATIVES TO CHEMICAL FUNGICIDES WILL PROVIDE TOOLS FOR DISEASE MANAGEMENT IN VEGETABLE PRODUCTION ESPECIALLY IN ORGANIC FARMING AND REDUCE USAGE OF TOXIC CHEMICALS IN CONVENTIONAL FARMING. INTEGRATED PEST MANAGEMENT (IPM) OF INSECT PESTS IS A HOLISTIC APPROACH TO SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURE THAT FOCUSES ON MANAGING PESTS THROUGH A COMBINATION OF CULTURAL, PHYSICAL, BIOLOGICAL AND CHEMICAL METHODS. IPM IS A CROP PROTECTION PRACTICE THAT IS COST EFFECTIVE, ENVIRONMENTALLY SOUND AND SOCIALLY ACCEPTABLE. TO FULFILL THIS NEED, WE CONDUCT RESEARCH FOCUSED ON CONDUCTING APPLIED RESEARCH EXPERIMENTS AND EDUCATING STAKEHOLDERS ON IPM THROUGH TRAINING AND PUBLICATIONS. IN-SERVICE TRAINING PROGRAMS FOR EXTENSION AGENTS AND IPM WORKSHOPS FOR OTHER STAKEHOLDERS ARE CONDUCTED ON STATE-WIDE BASIS IN EAST, MIDDLE AND WEST TENNESSEE REGIONS. IN OTHER INSECT RESEARCH, JAPANESE MAPLE SCALE RESEARCH, TIMED APPLICATIONS OF GROWTH REGULATORS AND ANNUAL MANAGEMENT PLANS DEVELOPED AT THE TSU NURSERY RESEARCH CENTER HAVE BEEN ADOPTED BY TENNESSEE GROWERS, REDUCING THE NUMBER OF REJECTED SHIPMENTS AND CULLED TREES. INVASIVE INSECTS ARE A MAJOR CONCERN IN NURSERY PRODUCTION. OUR RESEARCH IS PRODUCING DATA FOR NEW PESTICIDE REGULATIONS FOR FIRE ANT, JAPANESE BEETLE AND OTHER IMPORTANT INSECTS THAT ARE REDUCING WORKER EXPOSURE RISK, SAVING PRODUCERS TIME, AND OVERALL REDUCING THE COST OF PRODUCTION. MORE PRODUCER SAVINGS ARE EXPECTED WITH NEW PROTOCOLS UNDER DEVELOPMENT. SUSTAINABILITY RESEARCH WILL LEAD TO NEW PRACTICES THAT RESULTS IN REDUCTION OF INPUTS (PESTICIDES, FERTILIZER, WATER, LABOR, ETC.) IN THE NURSERY PRODUCTION SYSTEM, THUS ENHANCING THE SUSTAINABILITY OF THE INDUSTRY, IMPROVING OUR ENVIRONMENT, REDUCING PRODUCTION COSTS FOR GROWERS, IMPROVING CROP QUALITY, AND BROADENING THE MARKET FOR TENNESSEE GREEN INDUSTRY PRODUCTS. TO ADDRESS THE WELL-BEING AND HEALTH OF INDIVIDUALS, FAMILIES AND COMMUNITIES, RESEARCH IN FAMILY AND CONSUMER SCIENCES IS FOCUSED ON IMPROVING THE LIVES OF OUR STAKEHOLDERS THROUGH FCS EDUCATION, LEADERSHIP AND COMMUNICATION TO IMPROVE NOT ONLY THEIR HEALTH AND W ELL-BEING, BUT ALSO THEIR RELATIONSHIPS AND RESOURCES. THIS GROUP IS CONTINUING TO FOCUS ON EMERGENCY PREPAREDNESS, LIVING WITH CHRONIC DISEASES, FOOD SECURITY VIA FOOD RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, AND OF COURSE, MITIGATING THE EFFECTS OF COVID-19 AS WE LIVE THROUGH THE P ANDEMIC. TSU AGRICULTURE IS PROUD OF THE RESEARCH CONDUCTED BY OUR FACULTY AND STAFF AS WE CONTINUE TO ADDRESS ISSUES THAT ARE CRITICAL TO THE WELFARE OF OUR STAKEHOLDERS, AND CONTRIBUTING TO THE PROSPERITY OF THE CITIZENS OF TENNESSEE, THE NATION, AND THE WORLD. WE LOOK FORWARD TO CONTINUING TO FULFILL OUR UNIQUE ROLE AS AN HBCU LAND-GRANT INSTITUTION IN TENNESSEE AND TO CONTINUED GROWTH AND SUCCESS.

VIRGINIA STATE UNIVERSITY'S (VSU) AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH STATION (ARS) GENERATES SCIENTIFIC INFORMATION DESIGNED TO EXPAND KNOWLEDGE THAT WILL HELP SMALL, PART-TIME AND LIMITED-RESOURCE FARMERS BE PROFITABLE. THE RESEARCH FOCUS INCLUDES DEVELOPING PRODUCTION SYSTEMS THAT CONSERVE NATURAL RESOURCES, IMPROVING THE SUSTAINABILITY AND PROFITABILITY OF INDOOR AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION, DEVELOPING SUSTAINABLE PEST MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS FOR SMALL-SCALE AGRICULTURE AND IDENTIFYING NOVEL GENES THAT CAN BE USED TO IMPROVE CROP TOLERANCES TO ENVIRONMENTAL STRESSES. THE RESEARCH ALSO GENERATES SCIENTIFIC INFORMATION THAT IMPROVES THE PROFITABILITY AND HEALTH OF SMALL RUMINANTS. SCIENTISTS AT ARS WORK TO DEVELOP A RESILIENT FARMING SYSTEM THAT CAN COPE WITH THE ADVERSE IMPACTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE, COMPETITIVE AND SUSTAINABLE SMALL-SCALE AGRICULTURAL SYSTEMS, AND BIO-BASED ENERGY PRODUCTION SYSTEMS. THEY FURTHER AIM TO IMPROVE FOOD SAFETY AND QUALITY, AND TO GENERATE SCIENTIFIC INFORMATION ON VALUE-ADDED PLANT AND ANIMAL PRODUCTS TO IMPROVE THE PROFITABILITY OF FARMS. RESEARCH IS CONDUCTED ON CAMPUS AND AT A NEARBY VSU FARM TO ADDRESS THE FOLLOWING CRITICAL ISSUES: 1: AGRICULTURAL VIABILITY, PROFITABILITY AND SUSTAINABILITY O DEVELOP LOW-INPUT AND PROFITABLE INDOOR AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION SYSTEMS O IMPROVE THE SUSTAINABILITY AND PROFITABILITY OF SMALL RUMINANT PRODUCTION 2: BIOTECHNOLOGY, BIOMATERIALS, AND BIOENERGY O IDENTIFY NOVEL GENES THAT CAN BE USED TO IMPROVE CROP TOLERANCES TO ENVIRONMENTAL STRESSES, ESPECIALLY DROUGHT, HEAT AND METAL TOXICITY O USE GENETIC AND GENOME APPROACHES FOR BREEDING NEW CROPS TO ADDRESS GLOBAL CLIMATE CHANGE. 3: NATURAL RESOURCES, ENVIRONMENT AND CLIMATE CHANGE O DEVELOP A RESILIENT FARMING SYSTEM THAT CAN COPE WITH THE ADVERSE IMPACTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE O MINIMIZE THE EFFECTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE ON LOW INCOME COMMUNITIES

ALABAMA AGRICULTURAL AND MECHANICAL UNIVERSITY (AAMU) CONDUCTS RESEARCH PROJECTS THAT MEET THE NEEDS OF THE CITIZENS OF ALABAMA AND THE NATION. TO FULFILL OUR OBLIGATIONS UNDER USDA-NIFA EVANS ALLEN ACT OF 1890 (SECTION 1445) FOR FISCAL YEAR 2023, THERE ARE SEVERAL APPROVED PROJECTS. BROADLY, RESEARCH AREAS OF INTERESTS ARE: FOOD SYSTEMS AND FOOD SAFETY; GLOBAL FOOD SECURITY AND HUNGER; NATURAL RESOURCES AND ENVIRONMENTAL SUSTAINABILITY; HUMAN NUTRITION, WELL-BEING, HEALTH AND OBESITY; AND COMMUNITY AND REGIONAL PLANNING. FOOD SYSTEMS AND FOOD SAFETY: RESEARCH AND EXTENSION INTEGRATED ACTIVITIES ENHANCE FOOD SYSTEMS, FOOD SAFETY AND AGRICULTURAL BIOSEC URITY. THE GOAL OF THIS CRITICAL ISSUE IS TO DEVELOP TECHNOLOGY AND METHODS TO PROTECT AND ENHANCE THE SAFETY OF AGRICULTURE AND FOOD, REDUCE EPIDEMICS OF FOOD-BORNE ILLNESSES, AND TO DEVELOP THE KNOWLEDGE AND METHODOLOGIES FOR RAPID DETECTION OF THREAT AGENTS, IN CLUDING EXISTING AND EMERGING DISEASES OF PLANTS AND ANIMALS, RISK ASSESSMENT, AND FACILITY AND PERSONNEL SECURITY. GLOBAL FOOD SECURITY AND HUNGER: THE GOAL IS TO ENHANCE COMPETITIVENESS AND SUSTAINABILITY OF FOOD AND AGRICULTURAL INDUSTRIES IN ALABAMA THROUGH DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF BEST PRACTICES OR TECHNOLOGIES. THIS CRITICAL ISSUE ADDRESSES TWO BROADLY DEFINED PRIORITY AREAS; I) PLANT HEALTH AND PRODUCTION AND PLANT PRODUCTS, INCLUDING IMPROVED CROPPING SYSTEMS, PLANT BREEDING/GENOMICS, INTEGRATED PEST MANAGEMENT, PRECISION AGRICULTURE, ALTERNATIVE SPECIALTY CROPS; AND II) ANIMAL HEALTH AND PRODUCTION, INCLUDING IMPROVED FOOD-ANIMAL SYSTEMS AND STOCKS. OF PARTICULAR INTEREST ARE PROGRAMS AND PROJECTS THAT INCLUDE ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE AND EMERGING TECHNOLOGIES AND THAT PRESENT INNOVATIVE SYNERGIES OF DISCIPLINES AND PERSPECTIVES. HUMAN NUTRITION, WELL-BEING, HEALTH AND OBESITY: OBESITY, DIABETES, HIGH BLOOD PRESSURE, AND VASCULAR ISSUES ARE MOSTLY CAUSED BY THE LACK OF NUTRIENTS, THE LACK OF EXERCISE, POOR LIFESTYLE CHOICES, AND STRESS OF THE INVOLVED INDIVIDUALS. AS A RESULT OF THE GROWING HEALTH CONCERNS FOR ALABAMA CITIZENS, THERE HAS BEEN A COMBINED EFFORT TO EDUCATE AND MOTIVATE CITIZENS THROUGHOUT THE STATE TO MAKE BETTER HEALTH DECISIONS. THE OBJECTIVE IS TO IMPROVE THE HEALTH OF ALABAMIANS, TARGETING LIMITED-RESOURCE FAMILIES, THROUGH CHRONIC DISEASE AWARENESS, PHYSICAL ACTIVITY, NUTRITION EDUCATION, HEALTH LITERACY AND ACCESS TO AND CONSUMPTION OF FRESH FRUITS AND VEGETABLES. NATURAL RESOURCES AND ENVIRONMENTAL SUSTAINABILITY: THIS PROGRAM PLAN WILL GENERATE KNOWLEDGE TO MANAGE AGRICULTURAL AND NATURAL SYSTEMS IN THE FACE OF CLIMATE CHANGE AND THE NEED TO SUSTAIN NATURAL RESOURCES. SPECIFIC AREAS INCLUDE: CLIMATE-SMART SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURAL SYSTEMS, ENERGY CONSERVATION AND UTILIZATION OF RENEWABLE ENERGY RESOURCES; UNDERSTANDING THE LAND-WATER INTERFACE; CONSEQUENCES AND SOLUTIONS OF GLOBAL CLIMATE CHANGE; WATER QUALITY AND QUANTITY, CARBON SEQUESTRATION, NATURAL SYSTEMS RESTORATION, SURFACE AND GROUND WATERCONSERVATION; MANAGEMENT OF AGRICULTURAL WASTE RESIDUE; SUSTAINABLE SOIL HEALTH ENHANCEMENT; SUSTAINABLE ECO- AND AGRI-TOURISM; RURAL-URBAN INTERFACE ENVIRONMENTAL ISSUES; REMOTE SENSING AND PRECISION AGRICULTURE. COMMUNITY AND REGIONAL PLANNING: THIS AREA IS DESIGNED TO MAINTAIN THE INTEGRITY OF AGRICULTURAL LANDS THROUGH RURAL AND URBAN PLANNING PROGRAMS. APPROPRIATED FUNDS WILL BE USED FOR EXPENSES IN CONDUCTING RESEARCH TO INCLUDE FACULTY AND STAFF SALARIES, STUDENT SUPPORT, DISSEMINATION OF RESEARCH RESULTS, ADMINISTRATIVE PLANNING AND DIRECTION, EQUIPMENT PURCHASE AND MAINTENANCE, AND SUPPLIES PURCHASE (AMONG OTHER APPROVED SPENDING).

THE UNIVERSITY OF ARKANSAS AT PINE BLUFF (UAPB), SCHOOL OF AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND HUMAN SCIENCES HAS THREE ACADEMIC DEPARTMENTS, THE 1890 EXTENSION PROGRAM, THE 1890 RESEARCH PROGRAM, THE AQUACULTURE AND FISHERIES CENTER OF EXCELLENCE AND THE REGULATORY SCIENCE CENTER OF EXCELLENCE. RESEARCH FACULTY ARE INTEGRATED INTO THE ACADEMIC DEPARTMENTS. PERSONNEL WITH A MAJORITY EXTENSION APPOINTMENT ARE UNDER THE SUPERVISION OF THE ASSISTANT DEAN FOR EXTENSION. CONSISTENT WITH THE LAND GRANT MISSION, UAPB RESEARCH AND EXTENSION FACULTY HAVE A LONG HISTORY OF PROVIDING LEADERSHIP IN DEVELOPING AND DISSEMINATING INNOVATIVE PRACTICES AND EMERGING TECHNOLOGIES. HENCE, UAPB EXTENSION EDUCATORS DELIVER RESEARCHBASED EDUCATION TO THEIR CLIENTELE. OUR EXTENSION EDUCATORS EMPLOY DIVERSE EDUCATIONAL METHODS TO THEIR CLIENTELE, INCLUDING EDUCATIONAL FACETOFACE AND VIRTUAL FORUMS, LANDOWNER VISITS, INDIVIDUAL CONSULTATIONS, DEMONSTRATIONS, AND FIELD DAYS AND TOURS. ALTHOUGH THE INFORMATION IS READILYAVAILABLE IN THE DIGITAL AGE, UAPB REMAINS A DATA PROVIDER INDEPENDENT OF FINANCIAL OR PHILOSOPHICAL INTERESTS. THUS, THE PRIMARY CLIENTELE SERVED BY UAPBS EXTENSION PROGRAM ARE THE SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED, LIMITED RESOURCE AND UNDERSERVED FARMERS, RURAL FAMILIES, UNDERSERVED AND VULNERABLE YOUTH, THE ARKANSAS AQUACULTURE INDUSTRY, AND INDIVIDUALS AND AGENCIES WITH AN INTEREST IN FISHERIES AND FISH HABITATS. THESE CLIENTELE ARE SERVED THROUGH FIVE CRITICAL ISSUES OUTLINED BELOW. ENVIRONMENT, ENERGY AND CLIMATE: ARKANSAS HAS AN ABUNDANCE OF NATURAL RESOURCES, INCLUDING 19 MILLION ACRES OF FORESTS, 122,312 MILES OF RIVERS AND STREAMS, AND MORE THAN 600,000 ACRES OF LAKES AND RESERVOIRS. ARKANSAS HAS APPROXIMATELY 13,639,300 ACRES OF AGRICULTURAL LAND. MANY AFRICAN AMERICANS DO NOT SEE THEIR FOREST LAND AS AN ASSET BUT AS A LIABILITY. THE UAPB SUSTAINABLE FORESTRY AND LAND RETENTION PROGRAM WILL HELP PRODUCERS IMPROVE THEIR FOREST LAND AND SEE IT AS AN ASSET, TO EDUCATE AND ASSIST WITH HEIR PROPERTY ISSUES, AND ADDRESS THE LACK OF GOVERNMENT TRUST. ADDITIONALLY, SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED PRODUCERS ARE TAUGHT HOW TO USE SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURAL PRACTICES THAT KEEP SOILS, NUTRIENTS, AND PESTICIDES ON THEIR LAND AND PREVENT SOIL FROM SILTING AND POLLUTING STREAMS. ACCESS TO SAFE AND NUTRITIOUS FOOD: THE FOOD SAFETY MODERNIZATION ACT (FSMA) MADE FOOD SAFETY EDUCATION MANDATORY FOR LARGE FRESH FRUIT AND VEGETABLE PRODUCERS. HOWEVER, MANY GROCERY STORES REQUIRE ALL FARMERS TO BE GOOD AGRICULTURAL PRACTICES CERTIFIED. UAPBS EXTENSION WILL PROVIDE GAP AND FSMA TRAINING REQUIRED TO OBTAIN CERTIFICATION AND WE WILL STRENGTHEN AND ESTABLISH INFRASTRUCTURE TO IMPROVE FOOD SAFETY AWARENESS AND PRACTICES AMONG THE LOCAL SMALL, MEDIUM, AND LARGE SIZED FARMING OPERATIONS. INCREASING OPPORTUNITIES FOR YOUTH, FAMILIES AND COMMUNITIES: UAPBS EXTENSION ACTIVITIES FOCUS ON INCREASING OPPORTUNITIES FOR YOUTH, FAMILIES, AND COMMUNITIES. THE PROJECT WILL TARGET THE FAMILY WITH THE DESIRE TO SERVETHE COMMUNITY AT LARGE. 4H, FAMILY AND CONSUMER SCIENCE, AQUACULTURE/FISHERIES, AGRICULTURE AND HUMAN SCIENCES, AND EXTENSION PROFESSIONALS WILL ADDRESS ISSUES THAT IMPACT YOUTH, FAMILIES, AND COMMUNITIES. EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING CURRICULA AND PROGRAMS THAT REINFORCE COLLABORATION WITH YOUTH AND COMMUNITY BUSINESSES WILL ENSURE A COMPETENT WORKFORCE FOR COMMUNITIES. AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION AND PROCESSING: CHALLENGES FACING THIS CRITICAL ISSUE INCLUDE PRODUCTION EFFICIENCY, ADEQUATE WATER, SOIL HEALTH, RESISTANT PESTS, CLIMATE, ENVIRONMENTAL CONCERNS, ENERGY, RISING PRODUCTION COSTS, AND FOOD SAFETY. AQUACULTURE/FISHERIES EXTENSION PROVIDES FISH DISEASE DIAGNOSTICS SERVICES WHICH SAVE FARMERS THOUSANDS OF DOLLARS PER YEAR. THE APHISCERTIFIED LAB INSPECTS FISH SO THAT FARMERS CAN SELL DISEASEFREE FISH OUTOFSTATE. SPECIALTY CROP EXTENSION ACTIVITIES PRODUCE VIRUSINDEXED SWEET POTATO PLANTING MATERIALS FOR GROWERS AND DEVELOP VALUEADDED PRODUCTS SUCH AS SWEET POTATO WINES. AGRICULTURE AND NATURAL RESOURCES ECONOMICS AND MARKETING: UAPB OFFERS MANY SMALL AND SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED PRODUCERS ASSISTANCE WITH USDA LOAN APPLICATIONS. TO MEET THE FINANCIAL PLANNING NEEDS OF THIS GROUP OF EXISTING AND BEGINNING PRODUCERS, THE UAPB SMALL FARM PROGRAM CONTINUES TO OFFER FARM FINANCIAL PLANNING AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO PRODUCERS. MOSTLY, THIS WILL BE THE ONLY FARM BUSINESS TRAINING THAT THESE PRODUCERS N OBTAIN WITHIN THE REGION.

THE UMES EVANS ALLEN PROGRAM IS FOCUSED ON FOUR STRATEGIC AREAS: 1) AGRICULTURE AND FOOD, WITH A FOCUS ON FOOD SECURITY, 2) NATURAL RESOURCES AND ENVIRONMENTAL SUSTAINABILITY, 3) HUMAN HEALTH AND DEVELOPMENT, AND 4) PRODUCTS TO MARKET. FURTHERMORE, UMES STRIVES TO EDUCATE THE NEXT GENERATION OF TEACHERS, EDUCATORS, RESEARCHERS, AND SCIENTISTS IN THE FOOD, AGRICULTURAL AND RELATED SCIENCES. WHILE UMES' RESEARCH PROGRAMS ADDRESS THE NEEDS OF ALL MARYLANDERS, THE UNIVERSITY PLACES A SPECIAL EMPHASIS ON SERVING DIVERSE AND HISTORICALLY UNDERSERVED POPULATIONS. A BRIEF SUMMARY ON THE RESEARCH EMPHASIS UNDER EACH OF THE FOUR STRATEGIC AREAS OF FOCUS IS GIVEN BELOW: 1) AGRICULTURE AND FOOD WITH A FOCUS ON FOOD SECURITY: AGRICULTURE PLAYS A CRITICAL ROLE IN MARYLAND'S ECONOMY AND WILL CONTINUE TO DO SO FOR THE FORESEEABLE FUTURE. UMES RESEARCH WORK IN THIS AREA HAS A SPECIFIC FOCUS ON FOOD SAFETY AND SECURITY AND THIS IS UNDERTAKEN UNDER THE FOLLOWING THEMES: FOOD SAFETY AND QUALITY; AGRIBUSINESS AND ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT; ALTERNATIVE AGRICULTURE, SMALL-SCALE PRODUCTION, FAMILY FARMS AND URBAN AGRICULTURE; SPECIALTY CROPS, HONEY BEES, POULTRY, SMALL RUMINANTS AND LARGE SCALE AGRICULTURE. 2) NATURAL RESOURCES AND ENVIRONMENTAL SUSTAINABILITY: MARYLAND'S NATURAL RESOURCES UNDERPIN A RANGE OF ECONOMIC ACTIVITIES SUCH AS FORESTRY BASED INDUSTRIES, AGRITOURISM, FISHERIES, ETC., AND PROVIDE THE BASIS FOR SUPPORTING QUALITY LIVING FOR CITIZENS. CLIMATE CHANGE DOES IMPACT ALL THESE AREAS AND THE ESTABLISHMENT OF A STRONG AND SUSTAINABLE FOUNDATION TO GUIDE THE USE AND PROTECTION OF THESE RESOURCES IS A PRIORITY. TO THIS END, UMES RESEARCH AND EDUCATION ACTIVITIES WILL FOCUS ON SEVERAL KEY AREAS INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO WATER RESOURCES AND WATERSHED MANAGEMENT, WITH A FOCUS ON BOTH THE CHESAPEAKE BAY AND THE MARYLAND COASTAL BAYS. 3) HUMAN HEALTH AND DEVELOPMENT: THE HEALTH, SOCIAL AND ECONOMIC WELLBEING, AND RESILIENCE OF COMMUNITIES ARE IMPORTANT ISSUES FOR MARYLAND. RELEVANTRESEARCH WILL BE UNDERTAKEN IN THESE AREAS INCLUDING WORK IN NUTRITION AND DISEASE VECTORS 4) PRODUCTS TO MARKET: THE TRANSLATION OF RESEARCH FINDINGS TO APPLICATION BY INDUSTRY AND COMMUNITIES IS A CRITICAL COMPONENT OF OUR WORK. SEVERAL ACTIVITIES CONTRIBUTE TOWARDS THIS STRATEGIC AREA AND INCLUDE WORK FROM OUR INTERNATIONAL CENTER FOR PERSONAL PROTECTIVE EQUIPMENT, FOOD PROCESSING PROJECTS IN COLLABORATION WITH LOCAL ENTREPRENEURS AND FOOD COMPANIES, AND DEVELOPMENT OF MATERIALS, SUCH AS POLYMERS AND NANOMATERIALS FOR FOOD AND NON-FOOD USE. TO FULFILL MARYLAND'S RESEARCH GOALS, UMES HAS IDENTIFIED SEVEN IMPORTANT CRITICAL ISSUES. THESE ISSUES ARE DIRECTLY LINKED TO THE KEY STRATEGIC AREAS IDENTIFIED BY ESCOP AND THEY ALSO LINK DIRECTLY TO USDA-NIFA PRIORITIES. THESE ISSUES WILL BE THE FOCUS OF UMES' 2023-2027 PLAN OF WORK AND WILL BE USED TO DIRECT RESOURCES TO ACCOMPLISH THE SET GOALS. THE SEVEN ISSUES ARE AS FOLLOWS: 1. FOOD AND AGRICULTURE: SUSTAINABILITY, COMPETITIVENESS, AND PROFITABILITY OF FOOD AND AGRICULTURE. 2. CLIMATE CHANGE: ADAPTING TO AND MITIGATING THE IMPACTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE. 3. RENEWABLE ENERGY: ENERGY SECURITY AND THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE BIOECONOMY FROM RENEWABLE NATURAL RESOURCES. 4. SAFE, SECURE AND ABUNDANT FOOD SUPPLY: ENSURING A SAFE, SECURE AND ABUNDANT FOOD SUPPLY TECHNOLOGICAL INNOVATION, AND LEADERSHIP TO ENSURE A SAFE, SECURE, AND ABUNDANT FOOD SUPPLY. 5. HUMAN HEALTH, NUTRITION AND WELLNESS: IMPROVING HUMAN HEALTH, NUTRITION AND WELLNESS. 6. ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDSHIP: ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDSHIP AND SUSTAINABLE PRACTICES. 7. FAMILY AND COMMUNITY RESILIENCY: STRENGTHENING INDIVIDUAL, FAMILY AND COMMUNITY RESILIENCE.

THE FOLLOWING PROVIDES A HIGH LEVEL SUMMARY OF THE WORK WE INTEND TO SUPPORT WITH 1445 EVANS? ALLEN CAPACITY FUNDING AND MATCHING FUNDS PROVIDED BY THE STATE OF WEST VIRGINIA. WVSU ALIGNS ITS PROGRAMS WITHIN CRITICAL AREAS BASED ON ONGOING STAKEHOLDER INPUT AS WELL AS IDENTIFIED EMERGING ISSUES WITHIN THE STATE OF WEST VIRGINIA. FOOD ACCESS, SECURITY AND SAFETY <(>&<)> SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURE BOTH, IN URBAN AND RURAL AREAS IN WEST VIRGINIA, ACCESS TO HEALTHY AND SAFE FRESH FOOD IS A CHALLENGE FOR VULNERABLE POPULATIONS. INCREASED SUSTAINABLE PRODUCTION OF AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTS AND FOOD, IMPLEMENTATION OF PROPER PROCESSING/HANDLING OF FOOD AND FOOD PRODUCTS, AS WELL AS IMPROVED ACCESS TO QUALITY FRESH FOOD AND FOOD PRODUCTS ARE KEY ISSUES TO INCREASE FOOD SECURITY IN WEST VIRGINIA. THE APPALACHIAN REGION HAS UNIQUE THREATS AND OPPORTUNITIES AS IT RELATES TO ENVIRONMENTAL, WATER, ENERGY, FOOD AND NATURAL RESOURCES MANAGEMENT. ALL OF THESE ISSUES ARE INTERRELATED AND HAVE A SIGNIFICANT IMPACT ON AGRICULTURAL AND ECONOMIC ACTIVITIES THROUGHOUT THE STATE. OUR PROPOSED PLAN TO WORK ON AN ARRAY OF RESEARCH PROGRAMS WILL SUPPORT A DIVERSITY OF ENTERPRISES FOR CURRENT AND FUTURE FARMERS IN OUR STATE. RESEARCH PROGRAMS FOCUSED ON IMPROVEMENT OF THE SAFETY, QUALITY, AND SUSTAINABILITY OF SPECIALTY CROPS SUCH AS MICROGREENS, MUSHROOMS, TOMATOES, PEPPERS AND, OTHER CUCURBITS CROPS (MELON, WATERMELON, PUMPKIN, AND SQUASH) AS WELL AS AQUACULTURE PRODUCTION AND POLLINATOR HEALTH, WILL BENEFIT THE FARMERS IN WV CLIMATE CHANGE, ENERGY AND NATURAL RESOURCES MANAGEMENT THE APPALACHIAN REGION HAS UNIQUE THREATS AND OPPORTUNITIES AS IT RELATES TO ENVIRONMENTAL, WATER, ENERGY AND NATURAL RESOURCES MANAGEMENT. ONGOING ACTIVITIES OF THE EXTRACTIVE INDUSTRIES AND THE LEGACY OF POINT AND NONPOINT SOURCES OF POLLUTION CONTINUE TO BE MAJOR ENVIRONMENTAL AND ECOLOGICAL ISSUES AFFECTING WEST VIRGINIA'S AGRICULTURE, NATURAL RESOURCES, ITS LAND MANAGEMENT, AND THE WELLBEING OF ITS COMMUNITIES. LOOKING FORWARD, WEST VIRGINIA SEEKS TO DEVELOP SUSTAINABLE ALTERNATIVE AND CLEAN ENERGY SOURCES, ADDRESS LEGACY PROBLEMS, AND TO DEAL WITH FALLOUT FROM CLIMATE CHANGE. PROTECTION AND RESTORATION OF ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY AND ECOSYSTEM SERVICES AND THE DEVELOPMENT OF ECONOMICALLY EFFECTIVE AND ENVIRONMENTALLY SOUND AND SUSTAINABLE RESOURCE MANAGEMENT PRACTICES, WHILE EFFECTIVELY MITIGATING THE EFFECTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE, ARE ESSENTIAL STEPS FOR THE PROSPERITY OF THE STATE. WVSU RESEARCH PROGRAMS WILL WORK TO STUDY, PROTECT AND RESTORE ENVIRONMENTAL QUALITY AND ECOSYSTEM SERVICES WHILE DEVELOPING ECONOMICALLY EFFECTIVE AND ENVIRONMENTALLY SOUND AND SUSTAINABLE MANAGEMENT PRACTICES FOR ALTERNATIVE ENERGY/BIOENERGY, BIOPRODUCTS, AGRICULTURE, FORESTRY, MINING, AND RURAL COMMUNITIES AND ANTICIPATING AND ADAPTING. ADDITIONALLY, THE WVSU AGRICULTURAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL RESEARCH STATION WILL JOIN OUR FELLOW 1890 UNIVERSITIES IN A MULTISTATE MULTIDISCIPLINARY CONSORTIUM TO FURTHER DEVELOPMENT, IMPLEMENTATION, AND ADOPTION OF CLIMATESMART TECHNOLOGIES AND MANAGEMENT AND CONSERVATION PRACTICES, AND PROMOTE EQUITY AND ADVANCEMENT OF SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS, LANDOWNERS, AND COMMUNITIES OF COLOR.

NC A<(>&<)>T ENCOURAGES INNOVATIVE AND INTERDISCIPLINARY RESEARCH NECESSARY TO ADVANCE AGRICULTURAL TECHNOLOGY, SOLVE THE PROBLEM OF FOOD INSECURITY AND SAVE THE ENVIRONMENT. CAES CONDUCTS RESEARCH ON THE UNIVERSITY FARM, AT THE CENTER FOR ENVIRONMENTAL FARMING SYSTEMS IN GOLDSBORO (CEFS); AT THE CENTER OF EXCELLENCE IN POST-HARVEST TECHNOLOGIES (CEPHT) IN KANNAPOLIS; AND ON CAMPUS IN LABORATORIES WHERE INVESTIGATIONS INCLUDE AGRICULTURAL ECONOMICS, ANIMAL SCIENCE, SOIL SCIENCE, PLANT SCIENCE, HUMAN NUTRITION, FOOD SCIENCE AND BIOENERGY. THUS, CAES ENGAGES IN CUTTING-EDGE RESEARCH AND PROMOTES THE APPLICATION OF INTER- AND TRANS-DISCIPLINARY INTEGRATIVE APPROACHES THAT INCLUDE THE OUTREACH OF EXTENSION TO INCREASE CRITICAL MASS AND IMPACT. TO MOVE FORWARD WITH THIS AIM WE ARE FOCUSING ON FOUR INTEGRATIVE CLUSTERS (PRIORITIES): (1) PLANT AND ANIMAL AGRICULTURAL SYSTEMS; (2) FOOD SAFETY, NUTRITION AND HEALTH; (3) YOUTH, FAMILY AND COMMUNITY WELL-BEING; AND (4) ENVIRONMENTAL AND NATURALRESOURCES. SPECIFICALLY, RESEARCH AND EXTENSION AT NCA<(>&<)>T WILL CONTINUE TO OPEN DOORS AND MAKE AN IMPACT IN THE FOLLOWING WAYS: IMPROVING PLANT AND ANIMAL AGRICULTURAL SYSTEMS: WITHIN THIS AREA, WE WILL WORK TO ADDRESS CROSS-CUTTING AND EMERGING ISSUES OF ANIMAL AND PLANT HEALTH AND PRODUCTION. IN ANIMAL SYSTEM, RESEARCHERS WILL STUDY THE EFFICIENCY OF DIFFERENT FEEDING SOURCES TO IMPROVE ANIMAL PRODUCTIVITY AND GUT HEALTH. IN PLANT SYSTEMS, THE FOCUS WILL BE IN SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURE, ALTERNATIVE AND HIGH VALUE CROP PRODUCTION, SEASON EXTENSION, CLIMATE CHANGE ADAPTATION, VALUE ADDED AGRICULTURE, DIGITAL AGRICULTURE, SOIL HEALTH, PEST CONTROL, AGRO ECONOMICS. ENHANCING FOOD SAFETY, NUTRITION AND HEALTH: WITHIN THIS AREA, WE WILL WORK TO ADDRESS ISSUES OF HUMAN HEALTH, FOOD SAFETY AND HEALTHY LIVING HABITS. THE RESEARCH WILL FOCUS ON WHOLE GRAIN CEREALS, HUMAN HEALTH AND HUMAN NUTRITION, PROBIOTICS STRAINS, FOOD ALLERGY, FOOD PRODUCTION PROCESS, BIOACTIVE COMPOUNDS OF FOOD, POST-HARVEST TECHNOLOGY AND FOOD SECURITY. ENRICHING YOUTH, FAMILY AND COMMUNITY WELL-BEING: CAES RESEARCHERS ARE DEDICATED TO WORKING WITH NC'S MINORITY POPULATION, SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED AND DISABLED GROWERS, ELDERLY POPULATION, YOUTH, AND CHILDREN TO IMPROVE THEIR LIFESTYLE. RESEARCHERS WILL FOCUS ON THE CHALLENGES OF ELDERLY POPULATION, TEXTILE AND FASHION DESIGN, HEALTHY EATING HABITS AND CHILDHOOD OBESITY. ENVIRONMENTAL AND NATURAL RESOURCES: IN THIS AREA WE WILL WORK TO PROTECT THE NATURAL ENVIRONMENT, PROVIDE SOLUTIONS FOR WASTE MANAGEMENT AND CONVENTIONAL ENERGY. CAES RESEARCHERS WILL INVESTIGATE AN ADVANCED BIOLOGICAL SYSTEM TO PRODUCE ALTERNATIVE ENERGY, TREAT THE AGRICULTURAL AND INDUSTRIAL WASTE, AND PROTECT AND IMPROVE WATER QUALITY. CAES RESEARCHERS WILL BE INVOLVED IN A MULTISTATE CLIMATE CHANGE PROJECT TO STUDY THE IMPACT OF CLIMATE CHANGE ON SOCIALLY DISADVANTAGED FARMERS AND COMMUNITIES OF COLOR. RESEARCHERS WILL BE DEVELOPING THE ADAPTATION AND MITIGATION SOLUTION TO IMPROVE AGRICULTURE AND NATURAL RESOURCES, AND WILL BE PROPOSING POLICIES TO ADDRESS THE ISSUE OF ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE AND CLIMATE CHANGE.

SOUTHERN UNIVERSITY AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH AND EXTENSION CENTER UTILIZES THE SECTION 1445 FUNDING TO ADVANCE ITS AGENDA ASSOCIATED WITH FOOD AND AGRICULTURAL PROGRAMMING BENEFITING THE STATE OF LOUISIANA'S STAKEHOLDERS, AS REFLECTED IN ITS APPROVED FIVE-YEAR PLAN OF WORK (POW). INCIDENTALLY THIS PLAN IS ALSO COORDINATED BY THE STATE'S SISTER LAND GRANT INSTITUTION LOUISIANA STATE UNIVERSITY AGCENTER (LSU AGCENTER). THUS, THE POW CONSISTS OF ONE CONSOLIDATED AND INTEGRATED PLAN FOR BOTH THE RESEARCH AND EXTENSION PROGRAMS AT SOUTHERN UNIVERSITY AND LOUISIANA STATE UNIVERSITY. THE MISSION OF THE SU AG CENTER IS TO ENHANCE THE QUALITY OF LIFE FOR THE PEOPLE OF LOUISIANA THROUGH BASIC AND APPLIED RESEARCH AND EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS THAT ADDRESS SCIENTIFIC, TECHNOLOGICAL, SOCIAL, ECONOMIC AND CULTURAL NEEDS. THEREFORE, TO ADDRESS THE EMERGING NEEDS OF ITS STAKEHOLDERS, EMPHASIS IS PLACED ON THE FIVE PROGRAMMING AREAS IDENTIFIED AS CRITICAL FOR THE STATE, INCLUDING: (1) FAMILY <(>&<)> COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT: FOCUSES ON ISSUES AFFECTING INDIVIDUALS, FAMILIES, COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT; DISASTER, EPIDEMIC AND PANDEMIC PREPAREDNESS, MITIGATION AND RECOVERY; RISK AWARENESS; SUSTAINABLE HOUSING; AGROSECURITY; AND AGRITOURISM. (2) FOOD SECURITY <(>&<)> SYSTEMS: FOCUSED ON INCREASING THE SUSTAINABILITY AND PROFITABILITY OF LOUISIANA'S ANIMAL, AQUACULTURE AND PLANT SYSTEMS AND FOOD ACCESSIBILITY, AFFORDABILITY, POLICY; FOOD SAFETY, TO INCLUDE SEAFOOD, RAW PRODUCE, AND PROCESSED COMMODITY - SAFETY, CERTIFICATION PROGRAMS, FARM FINANCING AND SUCCESSION PLANNING ISSUES. (3) NATURAL RESOURCES <(>&<)> ENVIRONMENTAL SUSTAINABILITY: FOCUSES ON CONSERVATION AND PRESERVATION OF NATURAL RESOURCES, STATE'S FORESTRY INDUSTRY, WILDLIFE, WETLAND PLANTS, WATER, WASTE MANAGEMENT, LANDSCAPES, FEEDSTOCKS, ALTERNATIVE BIOFUELS, BIOMASS PROCESSING AND THEIR EFFECTS ON THE ENVIRONMENT. (4) OBESITY, HEALTH <(>&<)> WELLNESS FOCUSES ON INCREASED CONSUMPTION OF HEALTH FOODS - FRUITS AND VEGETABLES; INCREASING TIME IN PHYSICAL ACTIVITY; COMPLETE PHYSICAL; MENTAL AND SOCIAL WELL-BEING; POLICY, SYSTEM, AND ENVIRONMENT CHANGE; AND RELATED NUTRITION/HEALTH/WELLNESS ISSUES TO INCLUDE EPIDEMIC AND PANDEMIC PREVENTION; AND (5) YOUTH DEVELOPMENT: FOCUSES ON PROVIDING LOUISIANA YOUTH WITH POSITIVE DEVELOPMENT OPPORTUNITIES AND ACTIVITIES TO BUILD GREAT LEADERS AND HEALTHY CITIZENS. THESE PROGRAMS AND ASSOCIATED OUTCOMES ARE ACCESSIBLE TO STAKEHOLDERS ACROSS THE ENTIRE STATE OF LOUISIANA AND DISSEMINATED IN SEVERAL MODALITIES, INCLUDING RESEARCH CONDUCTED ON CAMPUS AND EXPERIMENTAL STATIONS, AND OFF-CAMPUS AT DIFFERENT STAKEHOLDERS AND PARTNER SITES. FACULTY, STUDENTS, STAFF, AND ADMINISTRATORS ACTIVELY PARTICIPATE IN PROGRAM DESIGN, DEVELOPMENT, DELIVERY AND ASSESSMENT. TO MEET THE EVER-CHANGING NEEDS OF OUR STAKEHOLDERS IN THE AGRICULTURE AND NATURAL RESOURCE COMMUNITIES AS WELL AS THE YOUTH AND FAMILIES SERVED BY OUR INSTITUTION, NEW APPROACHES TO CONDUCTING BUSINESS WILL BECOME THE NORM. INCREASEDRELIANCE ON NEW TECHNOLOGIES AND TOOLS SUCH AS SOCIAL MEDIA; INCREASED EXTERNAL FUNDING AND FUNDING FROM LOCAL ENTITIES; INCREASED COLLABORATION, AND TRAINED VOLUNTEERS WILL BECOME INCREASINGLY IMPORTANT AS WE ATTEMPT TO DELIVER HIGH QUALITY PROGRAMS TO LOUISIANA RESIDENTS. THE SU AG CENTER WILL CONTINUE ENSURING THAT THESE AND OTHER AVAILABLE RESOURCES ARE APPROPRIATELY ALLOCATED AND UTILIZED TO ASSURE A MAXIMUM RETURN ON INVESTMENT, HIGH RESPONSIVENESS AND RELEVANCE TO CRITICAL NEEDS, AND PROGRAM IMPACT.

THE UNIVERSITY OF KENTUCKY COLLEGE OF AGRICULTURE, FOOD AND ENVIRONMENT AND KENTUCKY STATE UNIVERSITY (KSU) COLLEGE OF AGRICULTURE, COMMUNITIES, AND THE ENVIRONMENT WERE FOUNDED AS LAND-GRANT INSTITUTIONS (1862 AND 1890, RESPECTIVELY), OFFERING ACCESS TO KNOWLEDGE AND LEARNING TO ENHANCE THE LIVES OF KENTUCKIANS. THE TWO PROGRAMS ARE FUNDAMENTALLY INTERDISCIPLINARY, APPLYING THE BIOLOGICAL, PHYSICAL, AND SOCIAL SCIENCES TO CHALLENGES IN AGRICULTURAL, FOOD, AND ENVIRONMENTAL SYSTEMS. OUR WORK ENCOMPASSES FARMS AND FORESTS, FOOD AND FIBER, FAMILIES, AND COMMUNITIES. THE UNIVERSITY OF KENTUCKY COLLEGE OF AGRICULTURE, FOOD AND ENVIRONMENT HOLDS A UNIQUE POSITION AS THE HOME OF THE KENTUCKY AGRICULTURAL EXPERIMENT STATION AND THE KENTUCKY COOPERATIVE EXTENSION SERVICE (KCES). THE TEACHING, RESEARCH, AND EXTENSION PROGRAMS ARE PART OF A NATIONAL SYSTEM THAT MAINTAINS A STATEWIDE PRESENCE AND LINKS LOCAL, STATE, NATIONAL AND GLOBAL ISSUES. THE KSU LAND GRANT PROGRAM AND COLLEGE OF AGRICULTURE, COMMUNITIES AND THE ENVIRONMENT FOCUSES ON TEACHING, RESEARCH, AND EXTENSION TO ADDRESS THE NEEDS OF THE SMALL-SCALE AND LIMITED- RESOURCE FARMERS; MINORITY AND UNDERSERVED/DISPARITY COMMUNITIES, AS WELL AS DIVERSE AND AT-RISK YO UTHS. THESE PROGRAMS INCLUDE RESEARCH TO IDENTIFY NEW AND NICHE PRODUCTS AND MARKETS FOR SMALL-SCALE, LIMITED RESOURCE, AND MINORITY FARMERS, TO ENHANCE AVAILABILITY AND SAFETY OF LOCALLY PRODUCED, NUTRITIOUS FOODS, AND REDUCE FERTILIZER AND PESTICIDE RUNOFF TO IMPROVE SOIL AND WATER QUALITY WHILE REDUCING FARMER AND FORESTER EXPENSES. OUR VISION IS TO BE RECOGNIZED FOR EXCELLENCE IN FOSTERING LEARNING THAT CHANGES LIVES, DISCOVERIES THAT CHANGE THE WORLD AND OPPORTUNITIES THAT SHAPE THE FUTURE. RESEARCH AND EXTENSION, AS FULL PARTNERS WITH EXPANDING LINKAGES THROUGHOUT THE UNIVERSITY OF KENTUCKY AND KSU AND WITH SUPPORT FROM EVERY KENTUCKY COUNTY, SEEK TO 1) FACILITATE LIFELONG LEARNING INFORMED BY SCHOLARSHIP AND RESEARCH, 2) EXPAND KNOWLEDGE THROUGH CREATIVE RESEARCH AND DISCOVERY, AND 3) SERVE KENTUCKIANS BY SHARING AND APPLYING KNOWLEDGE. RESEARCH AND EXTENSION SEEK TO SUSTAIN THE LAND-GRANT HERITAGE OF ACHIEVEMENT IN THESE CHALLENGING TIMES, BUT THE COMMONWEALTH AND THE UNIVERSITIES ARE UNDERGOING MANY SIGNIFICANT CHANGES. AS KENTUCKY CONTINUES TO MOVE FROM A TOBACCO-BASED AGRICULTURAL ECONOMY AND EXPLORES NEW OPTIONS AND COMMODITIES, LAND-GRANT PROGRAMS FACE INCREASED DEMANDS AND EXPECTATIONS. TECHNOLOGY IS REDEFINING THE WAY PEOPLE ACQUIRE AND DISTRIBUTE INFORMATION AND HOW THEY SOLVE PROBLEMS. WHILE URBANIZATION IS CLAIMING FARMLAND, IT IS ALSO CREATING NEW MARKETS FOR TRADITIONAL AND NON-TRADITIONAL AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTS. CHANGING LIFESTYLES AND DEMOGRAPHICS ARE CHALLENGING US WITH OPPORTUNITIES FOR GREATER INVOLVEMENT IN YOUTH, FAMILY, AND COMMUNITY PROGRAMS. WITH NEARLY 80,000 FARMS IN THE STATE AND AN AVERAGE 171 ACRES PER OPERATION, KENTUCKY IS DOMINATED BY SMALL FAMILY FARMS. HOWEVER, MANY OF THESE FARMS ARE MAJOR PRODUCERS OF TRADITIONAL AGRICULTURAL COMMODITIES, SUCH AS LIVESTOCK, TOBACCO, AND GRAIN. SOME SEEK NEW OPPORTUNITIES IN SPECIALTY CROPS AND INDUSTRIAL HEMP. OTHERS OPERATE ON A PART- TIME BASIS OR INVOLVE LIMITED RESOURCES. THE RESEARCH AND EXTENSION PROGRAMS AT BOTH LAND-GRANT INSTITUTIONS PROVIDE THE BREADTH NEEDED TO ADDRESS THE STATE'S DIVERSITY OF AGRICULTURAL OPERATIONS AND AGROECOSYSTEMS. MORE THAN HALF OF THE STATE'S CASH RECEIPTS FROM FARM MARKETS RESULT FROM ANIMALS AND ANIMAL PRODUCTS. SIGNATURE INDUSTRIES INCLUDE BEEF AND EQUINE, WHICH RELY ON CUTTING-EDGE RESEARCH TO MITIGATE FESCUE TOXICOSIS, CONTROL INFECTIOUS DISEASES AND IMPROVE REPRODUCTIVE EFFICIENCIES. ANIMAL PRODUCTION SYSTEMS, INCLUDING POULTRY, SWINE, SMALL RUMINANTS AND AQUACULTURE, ARE FACED WITH INCREASING PUBLIC PRESSURE TO ENSURE HIGH LEVELS OF ANIMAL WELFARE AND OPERATE IN ENVIRONMENTALLY SUSTAINABLE WAYS. THERE IS INCREASING INTEREST AMONG PRODUCERS FOR PRECISION ANIMAL MANAGEMENT TOOLS THAT CAN HELP INCREASE MARGINS AND A CONTINUED NEED FOR ASSISTANCE DEVELOPING AND MARKETING VALUE-ADDED PRODUCTS, PARTICULARLY FOR THE STATE'S DECLINING DAIRY INDUSTRY AND FOR SMALL AND LIMITED-RESOURCE FARMERS. SOYBEANS AND GRAIN CROPS HAVE BECOME INCREASINGLY IMPORTANT TO KENTUCKY AS THE TOBACCO INDUSTRY CONTINUES TO DECLINE. PRODUCERS RELY ON THE LAND-GRANTS FOR RESEARCH-BASED GUIDANCE ON MANAGING INTENSIVE PRODUCTION WITH MINIMAL ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT. RESEARCH AND EXTENSION PROGRAMS ADDRESS MANAGEMENT OF NUTRIENTS, PESTS AND DISEASES, VARIETY SELECTION IN A CHANGING CLIMATE AND WATER MANAGEMENT. THEY HELP PRODUCERS EFFECTIVELY USE PROVEN PRECISION FARMING AND LAND MANAGEMENT TOOLS. ADDITIONALLY, FORAGE SYSTEMS UNDERPIN THE STATE'S SIGNATURE EQUINE AND BEEF INDUSTRIES; THEIR MANAGEMENT CONTINUES TO BE A FOCUS FOR RESEARCH AND EXTENSION PROGRAMS IN THE STATE. HISTORICALLY, RURAL COMMUNITIES HAVE HAD MAJOR DEPENDENCE ON FARM INCOMES FOR THEIR ECONOMIC VIABILITY. WITH THE DECLINING POTENTIAL OF TOBACCO TO GENERATE FARM INCOME, DEVELOPMENT AND DISCOVERY OF NEW ENTERPRISES AND MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES ARE ESSENTIAL. THE LAND-GRANT SYSTEM WILL BE CHALLENGED TO FIND NEW STRATEGIES TO MEET THE DEMANDS FOR INCREASED DIVERSIFICATION IN RURAL COMMUNITIES. PROGRAMS IN SUPPORT OF HIGH-VALUE HORTICULTURAL CROPS, AQUACULTURE, INDUSTRIAL HEMP, DISTILLATION, WINE MAKING, BREWING AND NICHE-MARKET ANIMAL PRODUCTS ARE CRITICAL TO PROVIDING VIABLE ALTERNATIVES TO TOBACCO PRODUCTION. IN THE POST-TOBACCO-GROWING ERA, SUCCESSFUL RISK MANAGEMENT IS IMPORTANT IN MAINTAINING COMPETITIVENESS IN THE STATE'S AGRICULTURAL ECONOMY. VALUE OPPORTUNITIES IN AGRICULTURE CREATES JOBS, MANY WITHIN RURAL COMMUNITIES. VALUE OPPORTUNITIES ALSO CREATE EXPANDED DEMAND FOR LOCAL AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTS. INITIATIVES ARE REQUIRED TO ENCOURAGE LOCAL ENTREPRENEURIAL CREATIVITY AND RISK-TAKING AND TO BUILD A NETWORK OF SUPPORT RESOURCES. KENTUCKY IS MAKING SUBSTANTIAL RESOURCE COMMITMENTS TO SUPPORT THE CREATION OF AN "AGRITECH" ECOSYSTEM, AS WELL AS VALUE-ADDED INNOVATIONS THAT UTILIZE LOCAL AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTS, PARTICULARLY IN THE AREAS OF LIVESTOCK, HORTICULTURE, SECONDARY WOOD PRODUCTS, AND AGRITOURISM. THE CURRENT PUBLIC INTEREST IN COMMUNITY- AND REGION-BASED LOCAL FOOD SYSTEMS PROVIDES KENTUCKY'S RESEARCH AND EXTENSION PROGRAMS AN IDEAL OPPORTUNITY TO SHOWCASE RELEVANCE TO ALL CITIZENS ACROSS THE STATE AND ADDRESS ISSUES OF FOOD SECURITY, NUTRITION, PROSPERITY, AND SUSTAINABILITY IN BOTH RURAL AND URBAN COMMUNITIES. THE MISSION OF AN EFFECTIVE FOOD SAFETY SYSTEM IS TO PROTECT AND IMPROVE PUBLIC HEALTH BY ENSURING THAT FOODS MEET SCIENCE-BASED SAFETY STANDARDS. OVER 50% OF ALL FOOD-BORNE ILLNESS CAN BE ATTRIBUTED TO MISTAKES MADE IN FOOD SERVICE ESTABLISHMENTS AND RESTAURANTS, WHILE 20% ARE TRACEABLE TO CONSUMERS IN THEIR HOMES. CHANGES IN THE RISK OF FOOD-BORNE DISEASE ARE DUE PRIMARILY TO CHANGES IN DIET, INCREASED USE OF COMMERCIAL FOOD SERVICE AND FOOD PREPARED AND EATEN AWAY FROM HOME, NEW METHODS OF PRODUCING AND DISTRIBUTING FOOD, AND THE GROWING NUMBER OF AT-RISK INDIVIDUALS, SUCH AS THE ELDERLY AND THOSE WITH ELEVATED RISKS TO THEIR IMMUNE SYSTEMS. EDUCATIONAL TRAINING ON THE SAFE PRODUCTION, PREPARATION, HANDLING, AND STORAGE OF FOOD FOR PRODUCERS, PROCESSORS, CONSUMERS, AND AT-RISK GROUPS IS THE TRADITIONAL APPROACH TO DECREASE THE RISKS OF FOOD-BORNE ILLNESS. THREE LEADING CAUSES OF MORBIDITY AND MORTALITY IN KENTUCKY ARE CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASE, CANCER, AND DIABETES. THE RECOMMENDATIONS FOR THEIR PREVENTION AND TREATMENT OF THESE CHRONIC DISEASES INCLUDE STRONG NUTRITIONAL AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITY COMPONENTS. OBESITY IS A CONTRIBUTING FACTOR IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF THESE DISEASES. IN KENTUCKY, THE PREVALENCE OF OVERWEIGHT ADULTS HAS ESCALATED OVER THE LAST DECADES. EARLY DIAGNOSIS OF CANCER, DIABETES, AND CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASE IS ASSOCIATED WITH IMPROVED OUTCOMES, INCLUDING IMPROVED QUALITY OF LIFE AND LONGEVITY. PREVENTION, DETECTION, AND TREATMENT OF CHRONIC DISEASE IN KENTUCKY IS PARTICULARLY IMPORTANT IN TODAY'S CHANGING HEALTHCARE ENVIRONMENT. PEOPLE WITH CHRONIC DISEASES REQUIRE SKILLS FOR SELF-CARE. PUBLIC CONCERN OVER ECOSYSTEM ISSUES AS WELL AS NATIONAL AND STATE GOVERNMENT HAS GENERATED RECOGNITION OF THE NEED FOR RESEARCH AND EDUCATION PROGRAMS. KENTUCKY'S BIOLOGICAL WEALTH MAY CONTINUE TO BE THREATENED UNLESS COMPREHENSIVE AND SUSTAINABLE APPROACHES ARE RESEARCHED AND UTILIZED FOR ENJOYING, STUDYING, AND, AT THE SAME TIME, HARVESTING THE FRUITS OF THE LAND THROUGH LOGGING, MINING, AND AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION. ECOSYSTEM SERVICES MUST BE PRESERVED, ANTI-MICROBIAL RESISTANCE MUST BE MITIGATED AND POLLINATOR POPULATIONS MUST BE PROTECTED. APPROACHES MUST ALSO CONSIDER HOW THESE SYSTEMS ADAPT TO AND MITIGATE CLIMATE CHANGE. PROGRAMS MUST STRIVE TO ELUCIDATE HOW CLIMATE CHANGE WILL IMPACT AGRICULTURAL AND NATURAL RESOURCE SYSTEMS WHILE DEVELOPING PROGRAMS AND TECHNOLOGIES THAT WILL HELP FARMERS, FORESTERS, AND OTHERS ADAPT. THE LAND GRANT SYSTEM'S MISSION OF ENHANCING ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITY AND IMPROVING THE QUALITY OF LIFE FOR AMERICANS GOES WELL BEYOND A GRICULTURAL PRODUCTION. IT INCLUDES THE EMPOWERMENT OF PEOPLE AND COMMUNITIES THROUGH RESEARCH-BASED INFORMATION AND EDUCATION TO ADDRESS ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL CHALLENGES FACING OUR YOUTH, FAMILIES, AND COMMUNITIES. SOME CHALLENGES ARE: BOTH URBAN AND RURAL AREAS OF THE STATE CONTINUE TO BE PLAGUED BY HIGH UNEMPLOYMENT AND UNDEREMPLOYMENT. NEARLY 30% OF KENTUCKY'S YOUTH FAIL TO GRADUATE FROM HIGH SCHOOL. WITH MANY INDUSTRIES RELOCATING TO OTHER COUNTRIES, JOB CLOSINGS HAVE AFFECTED MANY AREAS OF THE STATE. MANY KENTUCKIANS LACK THE EDUCATIONAL PREPARATION AND SKILLS NEEDED TO SECURE AND MAINTAIN EMPLOYMENT OR QUALIFY FOR NEW-ERA JOBS. THROUGHOUT THEIR LIVES, BOTH YOUTH AND ADULT KENTUCKIANS NEED TO DEVELOP SKILLS ESSENTIAL TO BECOME PRODUCTIVE MEMBERS OF THE COMMUNITY AND WORKFORCE. BEING A PRODUCTIVE MEMBER OF SOCIETY AS AN ADULT REQUIRES YOUNG PEOPLE TO GAIN EXPERIENCE AS ACTIVE CITIZENS ATAN EARLY AGE. 4-H COMMUNITY SERVICE ACTIVITIES PROVIDE LEARNING EXPERIENCES THAT HELP YOUTH DEVELOP LIFE SKILLS NEEDED TO BE EFFECTIVE IN VARIOUS ADULT ROLES IN SOCIETY. OUR GOAL IS TO IMPROVE THE CAPACITY OF COMMUNITIES TO IDENTIFY AND ADDRESS THESE CRITICAL ISSUES, AND OTHERS THAT AFFECT THE LIVES OF CITIZENS. WE CAN BEST DO THIS BY FOSTERING THE DEVELOPMENT OF PERSONAL AND INTERPERSONAL SKILLS, STIMULATING VOLUNTEER LEADERSHIP, AND PROMOTING ACTIVE PARTICIPATION IN COMMUNITY PROBLEM-SOLVING. WITHOUT THE ACQUISITION OF LIFE SKILLS NEEDED BY YOUNG PEOPLE AND ADULTS, IT IS DOUBTFUL THE CITIZENS OF KENTUCKY WILL REACH THEIR FULL POTENTIAL AS BOTH INDIVIDUALS AND AS MEMBERS OF FAMILIES. WE APPROACH KENTUCKY'S CHALLENGES THROUGH AN INTEGRATED MODEL THAT INCLUDES A NEEDS ASSESSMENT CONDUCTED AT THE GRASSROOTS LEVEL THROUGH THE COOPERATIVE EXTENSION SERVICE, ADVISORY GROUPS, COUNCILS, AND COMMITTEES. ONCE IDENTIFIED AS PRIORITIES, SPECIFIC PROBLEMS AND NEEDS ARE ADDRESSED BY OUR RESEARCHERS AND EXTENSION SPECIALISTS. THE RESEARCH, DEVELOPMENTS, FINDINGS, AND TECHNOLOGIES ARE TRANSFERRED THROUGH TRADITIONAL AND INNOVATIVE MECHANISMS, INCLUDING EDUCATIONAL AND TRAINING PROGRAMS, TECHNOLOGY TRANSFER, RESEARCH REPORTS, AND PARTNERSHIPS WITH OTHER COLLEGES, UNIVERSITIES, AND STATE AND LOCAL GOVERNMENTS. WHETHER IT IS PRESERVING OUR RICH AGRICULTURAL TRADITION BY HELPING FARMERS, FOOD PROCESSORS, AND AGRIBUSINESS COPE WITH TECHNICAL ISSUES, REACHING GOALS, OR ENHANCING THE LIFE SKILLS OF FAMILIES, OUR RESEARCH, EDUCATION, AND EXTENSION PROGRAMS ARE HELPING SHAPE THE FUTURE OF KENTUCKY'S AGRICULTURE, FOOD SYSTEMS, AND COMMUNITIES AS WELL AS THE QUALITY OF LIFE OF ITS CITIZENS. CRITICAL ISSUES FOR RESEARCH AND EXTENSION LIFE SKILLS DEVELOPMENT DESCRIPTION: THIS CRITICAL ISSUE PROMOTES THE ACQUISITION OF LIFE SKILLS NEEDED BY YOUTH AND ADULTS TO REACH THEIR FULL POTENTIAL. ISSUES ABOUND IN EARLY CHILDHOOD DEVELOPMENT, YOUTH DEVELOPMENT, FAMILY WELL-BEING, ETHICS, CHARACTER EDUCATION, LIFE SKILLS, MONEY AND RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, RETIREMENT SAVINGS, SOCIAL ENTREPRENEURSHIP, COMMUNICATION AND INFORMATION DELIVERY, AND MORE. KCES WILL EXPAND EDUCATIONAL OUTREACH IN STEM/STEAM AREAS THAT WILL INCREASE ENROLLMENT OF LIMITED-RESOURCE FAMILIES AND COMMUNITIES WHO ARE AT OR BELOW THE POVERTY LEVEL AND WHO QUALIFY FOR SUPPORT SERVICES TERM: INTERMEDIATE SCIENCE EMPHASIS AREAS EDUCATION AND MULTICULTURAL ALLIANCES FAMILY <(>&<)> CONSUMER SCIENCES YOUTH DEVELOPMENT NUTRITION AND HEALTHY LIFESTYLES

THE GEORGIA PLAN OF WORK (POW) ENCOMPASSES A FIVE-YEAR PERIOD BEGINNING OCTOBER 1, 2022. THE PLAN ADDRESSES MAJOR AGRICULTURAL ISSUES AS WELL AS MANY OTHER PROBLEMS FACING RURAL AND URBAN AREAS, THE ENVIRONMENT, FAMILIES AND YOUTH. THE PLAN REPRESENTS A COORDINATED EFFORT BETWEEN THE STATE'S 1890 AND 1862 LAND-GRANT INSTITUTIONS, FORT VALLEY STATE UNIVERSITY (FVSU) AND THE UNIVERSITY OF GEORGIA (UGA), AND INCLUDES JOINT PLANNING BETWEEN EXPERIMENT STATIONS AND COOPERATIVE EXTENSION UNITS AT BOTH UNIVERSITIES. GEORGIA, ONE OF THE ORIGINAL 13 COLONIES, HAS A LAND AREA OF 57,701 SQUARE MILES AND A WATER AREA OF 1,706 SQUARE MILES, WHICH MAKES IT THE LARGEST STATE EAST OF THE MISSISSIPPI RIVER (21TH OVERALL). GEORGIA FALLS WITHIN FIVE MAJOR PHYSIOGRAPHIC REGIONS: THE BLUE RIDGE MOUNTAINS IN THE NORTHEAST; THE RIDGE AND VALLEY PROVINCE AND THE CUMBERLAND PLATEAU IN THE NORTHWEST; THE PIEDMONT ACROSS CENTRAL GEORGIA; AND THE COASTAL PLAIN IN THE SOUTH. ELEVATIONS RANGE FROM SEA LEVEL TO 4,784 FEET AT BRASSTOWN BALD IN THE BLUE RIDGE MOUNTAINS. THE 2020 CENSUS ESTIMATED GEORGIA'S POPULATION WAS 10,711,908 AND REPORTED 23.8% OF GEORGIANS ARE UNDER AGE 18 AND 13.9% ARE 65 OR OLDER. ACCORDING TO THE CENSUS,51.9% OF GEORGIANS IDENTIFY THEMSELVES AS WHITE/CAUCASIAN, 31% AS BLACK/AFRICAN-AMERICAN, 4.5% AS ASIAN,.5% AS AMERICAN INDIAN/ALASKA NATIVE, .1% AS NATIVE HAWAIIAN/PACIFIC ISLANDER, AND 6.9% AS MORE THAN ONE RACE. IT WAS ALSO REPORTED THAT 10.5% OF GEORGIANS IDENTIFY AS HISPANIC OR LATINO. GEORGIA'S COOPERATIVE EXTENSION PROGRAM HAS 167 OFFICES, WITH PROGRAMMING IN ALL OF GEORGIA'S 159 COUNTIES. FVSU AND UGA PERSONNEL ARE HOUSED JOINTLY IN COUNTY OFFICES. EXTENSION DELIVERS PROGRAMMING IN AGRICULTURE AND NATURAL RESOURCES, FAMILY AND CONSUMER SCIENCES, AND 4-H YOUTH DEVELOPMENT AS BOTH INDIVIDUAL COUNTY EFFORTS AND AS MULTICOUNTY PROGRAMS. STATE FACULTY MEMBERS DELIVER TRAINING TO COUNTY AGENTS AND PROGRAMMING DIRECTLY TO CLIENTELE, WHEN APPROPRIATE. FVSU AND UGA RESEARCHPROGRAMS ARE CONDUCTED THROUGH THE AGRICULTURAL EXPERIMENT STATION SYSTEM. GEORGIA HAS SEVERAL CAMPUSES THROUGHOUT THE STATE; ITS FOUR LARGEST ARE LOCATED IN ATHENS, FORT VALLEY, TIFTON AND GRIFFIN. GEORGIA HAS ELEVEN RESEARCH AND EDUCATION CENTERS STRATEGICALLY LOCATED THROUGHOUT THE STATE. THIS JOINT PLAN OF WORK WAS DEVELOPED AROUND CORE PROGRAMS AND TARGETED ISSUES. USING A STRUCTURED PROGRAM DEVELOPMENT SYSTEM, GEORGIA DEVELOPS CORE PROGRAM DIRECTIONS AND IDENTIFIES TARGETED ISSUES. THE GEORGIA PROGRAM DEVELOPMENT MODEL IS A MULTISTEP PROCESS THAT IS OPERATIONAL EVERY YEAR. THE MODEL INCLUDES A METHOD FOR ASSESSING NEEDS AND IDENTIFYING PROBLEMS. IT ALSO INCLUDES PROGRAM EVALUATION TO DETERMINE IMPACT. THE GEORGIA PROGRAM DEVELOPMENT MODEL WORKS IN UNISON WITH MULTIPLE ADVISORY SYSTEMS AT BOTH COUNTY AND STATE LEVELS. INPUT SOLICITED DIRECTLY FROM ACADEMIC DEPARTMENTS AT FVSU'S COLLEGE OF AGRICULTURE, FAMILY SCIENCES AND TECHNOLOGY AS WELL AS UGA'S COLLEGE OF AGRICULTURAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES (CAES) AND COLLEGE OF FAMILY AND CONSUMER SCIENCES AS PART OF THE ANNUAL NEEDS ASSESSMENT IS AN INTEGRAL PART OF DEVELOPING THIS PLAN OF WORK. FACULTY MEMBERS ASSOCIATED WITH THIS PLAN ARE WORKING ON CUTTING-EDGE PROGRAMS. THEY PROVIDE INFORMATION AND INPUT FROM BOTH THE ACADEMIC LITERATURE AND PERSONAL KNOWLEDGE. THIS INPUT IS EQUALLY IMPORTANT TO PROGRAM DEVELOPMENT AS IS A STRONG ADVISORY SYSTEM. THE GEORGIA FEDERAL PLAN OF WORK DOES NOT ATTEMPT TO CAPTURE ALL OF THE WORK OF THE COLLEGES' FACULTY MEMBERS. IT IS INTENDED TO DOCUMENT THE PLANS AND ACTIONS OF THE FACULTY MEMBERS RECEIVING SPECIFIC FORMULA FUNDS. THE MAJORITY OF THESE FUNDS ARE USED TO SUPPORT STATE-LEVEL CORE PROGRAMS. THESE CORE PROGRAMS COVER A WIDE RANGE OF TOPICS, INCLUDING TRADITIONAL ANIMAL AND PLANT PRODUCTION, POSITIVE YOUTH AND FAMILY DEVELOPMENT, URBAN AGRICULTURE, PERSONAL HEALTH AND WELL- BEING, AND EMERGING ISSUES, SUCH AS BIOFUELS. THE GOALS OF THESE PROGRAMS ARE TO DEMONSTRATE SHORT-AND LONG-TERM IMPACT. HOWEVER, THE GREATEST IMPACTS OF THESE CORE PROGRAMS ARE THE FOUNDATIONS CREATED TO SUPPORT AND LEVERAGE ADDITIONAL RESOURCES BEYOND STATE-MATCHING FUNDS. THE ADDITIONAL STATE FUNDING, COUNTY FUNDING, GRANTS AND GIFTS LEVERAGED AS A DIRECT RESULT OF THE WORK IN THIS PLAN MAY CREATE THE GREATEST FINAL IMPACT. MOST OF GEORGIA'S PLANNED PROGRAMS INCLUDE OUTCOME MEASURES THAT TRACK THE OUTPUT LEVELS OF LEVERAGED PROGRAMMING. THE OUTPUTS OF THESE LEVERAGED PROGRAMS ARE CONSIDERED A DIRECT, SHORT-TERM OUTCOME OF THE CORE PLANNED PROGRAMS WITHIN THE GEORGIA FEDERAL PLAN OF WORK. THE GEORGIA FEDERAL PLAN OF WORK IS CENTERED ON EIGHT PLANNED PROGRAMS. THESE WORK IN CONJUNCTION WITH EACH OTHER TO ADDRESS IMPORTANT ISSUES ON COUNTY, STATE, REGIONAL, NATIONAL AND GLOBAL LEVELS. ANIMAL PRODUCTION THIS PLAN OF WORK WILL EXPLORE DIFFERENT AREAS OF ANIMAL PRODUCTION AND PROTECTION, FOCUSING ON THE PRODUCTION OF SHEEP, GOATS, DAIRY AND BEEF CATTLE, SWINE, POULTRY, AQUACULTURE, AND SMALL RUMINANTS. EQUINE AND BEES ARE ALSO INCLUDED. SPECIFIC TOPICS FOR THIS PROGRAM INCLUDE, BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO: GEORGIA BEEF CHALLENGE, MASTER CATTLEMAN'S PROGRAM, PROFITABILITY OF DAIRY FARMING, SWINE INTAKE REGULATION, IPM AND EVALUATION OF NEW FORAGES AND FEEDS. COMMUNITY, HOME AND LIFE SKILLS THIS PLAN OF WORK WILL EXPLORE ISSUES RELATED TO HOME AND LIFE SKILLS. SPECIFIC TOPICS FOR THIS PROGRAM INCLUDE, BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO: COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT, ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT, INDOOR AIR QUALITY, WATER QUALITY, WASTE MANAGEMENT, ENERGY MANAGEMENT, HOMEBUYER EDUCATION, CONSUMER ECONOMICS, FINANCIAL LITERACY, AND EMERGENCY PREPAREDNESS. FOOD SAFETY AND QUALITY THIS PLAN OF WORK WILL EXPLORE DIFFERENT AREAS OF FOOD SAFETY, FOCUSING ON FOOD PROCESSING, PROTECTION, AND SAFETY; PLANT PRODUCTION; AND ANIMAL PRODUCTION AND PROTECTION. SPECIFIC TOPICS FOR THIS PROGRAM INCLUDE, BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO: CONSUMER DEMAND FOR FOOD, FOOD INDUSTRY NEEDS, AND THE FOOD PROCESSING INDUSTRY. HEALTH ANDWELLNESS THIS PLAN OF WORK WILL EXPLORE ISSUES OF CHRONIC DISEASE PREVENTION AND HEALTHY LIFESTYLES, FOCUSING ON WEIGHT CONTROL, PHYSICAL ACTIVITY, DIABETES MANAGEMENT AND PREVENTION, CARDIOVASCULAR DISEASES PREVENTION AND CANCER PREVENTION TO THE PUBLIC. A LARGE FOCUS OF THIS PROGRAM WILL BE ON THE STATE'S YOUTH. PLANT PRODUCTION THIS PLAN OF WORK WILL EXPLORE PLANT PRODUCTION AND PROTECTION. SPECIFIC TOPICS FOR THIS PROGRAM INCLUDE, BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO: PLANT GROWTH AND CROP PRODUCTION; PLANT DISEASES, WEEDS AND PESTS; DEVELOPING NEW BREEDING TOOLS; SOIL QUALITY; IRRIGATION; PLANT PATHOLOGY; GENETICS; ENTOMOLOGY; IPM, HARVEST AND POST-HARVEST HANDLING; CONSERVATION; CULTURAL TRENDS; AND BREEDING PROGRAMS THAT INCORPORATE VARIABILITY DERIVED FROM INTERSPECIFIC HYBRIDS FROM WHICH NEW CULTIVARS CAN BE DEVELOPED. SUSTAINABILITY, CONSERVATION AND THE ENVIRONMENT THIS PLAN OF WORK WILL EXPLORE ISSUES RELATED TO THE SUSTAINABILITY AND PROFITABILITY OF AGRICULTURE. SPECIFIC TOPICS FOR THIS PROGRAM INCLUDE, BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO: NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, MINIMUM TILLAGE AND COVER CROPS; VALUE ADDED PRODUCTS OR PRODUCTION PRACTICES THAT CAN IMPROVE SUSTAINABILITY AND PROFITABILITY; INVESTIGATION OF NICHE MARKETS IN GEORGIA; FINANCIAL ACCOUNTING AND REPORTING STRATEGIES; AND ALTERNATE CULTURAL PRACTICES THAT WILL PROTECT, IMPROVE AND MAINTAIN SOIL FERTILITY. URBAN AGRICULTURE THIS PLAN OF WORK WILL EXPLORE ISSUES RELATED TO URBAN AGRICULTURE. SPECIFIC TOPICS FOR THIS PROGRAM INCLUDE, BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO: WATER CONSERVATION TECHNOLOGY AND TRAINING; TURF DISEASE IDENTIFICATION AND MANAGEMENT; IPM; DEVELOPMENT OF NEW COST ESTIMATING AND JOB BIDDING SOFTWARE FOR LANDSCAPE INSTALLATION; AND MASTER GARDENER PROGRAMS. YOUTH AND FAMILY DEVELOPMENT THIS PLAN OF WORK WILL EXPLORE POSITIVE YOUTH AND FAMILY DEVELOPMENT. SPECIFIC TOPICS FOR THIS PROGRAM INCLUDE, BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO: PARENTING; RELATIONSHIPS, CHILD AND ELDERLY CARE; 4-H AND YOUTH PROGRAMMING. THE GEORGIA FEDERAL PLAN OF WORK IS DESIGNED TO MEET THE EMERGING ISSUES OF OUR COMMUNITIES, SUPPORT THE SUSTAINABILITY AND PROFITABILITY OF THE AGRICULTURE INDUSTRY AND PROVIDE EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS FOR FAMILIES AND YOUTH. MAJOR COMPONENTS IN THE PLANNED PROGRAM SPECIFICALLY TARGET YOUTH AND FAMILIES AT RISK. OTHER COMPONENTS TARGET SMALL PRODUCERS, LIMITED RESOURCES FARMERS AND RURAL COMMUNITIES. II. MERIT / PEER REVIEW PROCESS UGA CAES AND FVSU INDEPENDENTLY AND COLLABORATIVELY CONDUCT PERIODIC, EXTENSIVE AND COMPREHENSIVE PROGRAM REVIEWS OF THEIR RESEARCH AND EXTENSION PROGRAMS. THESE REVIEWS COLLECT BOTH INTERNAL AND EXTERNAL INPUT, INCLUDING INPUT FROM FACULTY AND STAFF, CLIENTELE, ALUMNI AND STAKEHOLDER GROUPS. THE RESULTS OF THESE REVIEWS HAVE BEEN USED TO FORMULATE THIS PLAN OF WORK. ADDITIONALLY, THE UNIVERSITIES HAVE SOUGHT GUIDANCE FROM THE UGA CAES ADVISORY SYSTEM AND THE FVSU CAFST ADVISORY BOARD THROUGH THEIR CRITICAL REVIEW OF PROGRAMS AND SUGGESTIONS FOR IMPROVEMENTS. THIS PLAN OF WORK IS UNDER CONTINUOUS REVIEW BY THE PROGRAM DEVELOPMENT TEAM, WHICH IS COMPRISED OF PROGRAM DEVELOPMENT SPECIALISTS AND COORDINATORS FROM AGRICULTURE AND NATURAL RESOURCES, FAMILY AND CONSUMER SCIENCES AND 4- H YOUTH DEVELOPMENT, AS WELL AS FACULTY FROM BOTH FVSU AND UGA. THIS REVIEW IS AN ONGOING PROCESS, AND FUTURE ANNUAL REVIEWS AND CHANGES TO THE PLAN OF WORK WILL BE THE RESPONSIBILITY OF THIS TEAM. THE RESEARCH PORTION OF THE PLAN OF WORK UNDERGOES SCIENTIFIC PEER REVIEW PRIOR TO EACH PROJECT BEING SUBMITTED. ALL SCIENTISTS ARE REQUIRED TO HAVE ACTIVE PROJECTS FOR EXPENDITURES TO BE MADE. EACH PROJECT IS PEER-REVIEWED BY BOTH INTERNAL AND EXTERNAL REVIEWERS AND MUST BE APPROVED BY THE APPROPRIATE DEAN AND DIRECTOR PRIOR TO SUBMISSION TO THE NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF FOOD AND AGRICULTURE. III. STAKEHOLDER INPUT 1. ACTIONS TO SEEK SURVEYS ARE USED AT THE PLANNED PROGRAM LEVEL. INFORMATION IS COLLECTED AND SHARED AS PART OF THE PROGRAM DEVELOPMENT PROCESS. THE ADVISORY SYSTEM REQUIRESTHAT FACULTY SEEK PARTICIPATION BY NONTRADITIONAL STAKEHOLDER INDIVIDUALS. GEORGIA'S ADVISORY SYSTEM ALSO RECOMMENDS THAT ADVISORY COMMITTEE MEMBERSHIP REFLECT THE DEMOGRAPHIC COMPOSITION OF THE COMMUNITY. 2. METHODS TO IDENTIFY FACULTY AND ADMINISTRATION IDENTIFY ORGANIZATIONS MADE UP OF DIRECT STAKEHOLDERS OR POTENTIAL COLLABORATORS IN ADDRESSING COMMUNITY ISSUES. INPUT IS SOUGHT FROM STAKEHOLDERS WHO HAVE DEMONSTRATED THEIR DEDICATION TO THE ACTIVITIES OF THE COLLEGE. COUNTY PROGRAMS IDENTIFY INDIVIDUALS WITH THE ABILITY TO REPRESENT DIVERSE CURRENT OR POTENTIAL STAKEHOLDER GROUPS IN THE COMMUNITY. RACE, ETHNICITY, INCOME OR COMMUNITIES OF INTEREST MAY BE USED TO IDENTIFY THESE GROUPS. 3. METHODS TO COLLECT AT THE LOCAL LEVEL, ADVISORY COMMITTEES MEET BY PROGRAM AREA TO CUMULATIVELY IDENTIFY ISSUES; PLAN, EXECUTE AND EVALUATE PROGRAMS; AND COMMUNICATE RESULTS TO THE COMMUNITY. WHEN MAKING HIRING DECISIONS, COMMENTS AND RECOMMENDATIONS OF ACTIVE STAKEHOLDERS ARE SOLICITED VIA EMAIL SURVEY. 4. HOW CONSIDERED STAKEHOLDER INPUT IS AN IMPORTANT PART OF GEORGIA'S PROGRAM DEVELOPMENT MODEL. STAKEHOLDER INPUT IS CURRENTLY USED FOR PROGRAM PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT PURPOSES, AND TO IDENTIFY AND EVALUATE RESOURCE LEVELS DIRECTED TOWARD SPECIFIC PLANNED PROGRAMS. STAKEHOLDERS ARE ENCOURAGED TO PARTICIPATE IN PROGRAM IMPLEMENTATION AS A TOOL TO UNDERSTAND THE VALUE AND SCOPE OF THE PROGRAM. STAKEHOLDERS ARE ALSO PART OF FUND DEVELOPMENT AT BOTH THE STATE AND LOCAL LEVELS. IV.
